æˆ‘å€‘æ‡‰ç•¶å•ï¼šã€Œæ˜¯ä»€éº¼åœ¨å»¶çºŒè¼ªè¿´ï¼Ÿæ‡‰å¦‚ä½•æ¨é›¢ï¼Ÿã€

é€™æ­£æ˜¯å¤§æ‹˜çµºç¾…å°Šè€…èˆ‡èˆåˆ©å¼—å°Šè€…è¨è«–çš„ä¸»é¡Œã€‚

è‹¥å…­è™•ï¼ˆÄyatanaï¼‰éƒ½å·²æ­¢æ¯ï¼Œæ˜¯å¦é‚„æœƒæœ‰ç…©æƒ±ï¼ˆkilesaï¼‰ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Ÿ
èˆåˆ©å¼—å°Šè€…çš„å›ç­”ç‚ºï¼š

ã€Œä¸èƒ½é€™æ¨£å•ã€‚ã€

äº”è™•ç‚ºè‰²æ ¹ï¼ˆçœ¼ã€è€³ã€é¼»ã€èˆŒã€èº«ï¼‰ï¼ŒåŠ ä¸Šæ„æ ¹ï¼ˆmanaï¼‰ï¼Œå…±æˆå…­æ ¹ã€‚
ç•¶å…­æ ¹æ­¢æ¯ï¼Œæ˜¯å¦é‚„æœ‰ä»»ä½•å­˜åœ¨ï¼Ÿé€™æ¨£å•æ³•æœ¬èº«å·²è½å…¥é‚ªè¦‹ã€‚

äº‹å¯¦æ˜¯ï¼š

åœ¨æ­¢æ¯è™•ï¼ˆnirodhaï¼‰å‡ºç¾çš„ï¼Œæ˜¯æ¶…æ§ƒï¼Œè€Œéã€ŒæŸç‰©ã€çš„å»¶çºŒã€‚

æ¶…æ§ƒä¸¦éæŸç¨®å­˜åœ¨æˆ–æœ‰æƒ…é«”çš„å»¶çºŒï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ï¼š

ä¸€åˆ‡æˆ²è«–æ­¢æ¯ä¹‹è™•ï¼ˆni-papaÃ±caï¼‰

è‹¥ä½ ä»æƒ³è¿½å•ï¼šã€Œé‚£æ˜¯å¦æœ‰ä»€éº¼ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Ÿã€

è‹¥æˆ²è«–å·²æ–·ï¼Œå³æ˜¯æ¶…æ§ƒç¾å‰ã€‚é€™é»ç„¡é ˆæ‡·ç–‘ã€‚

å°æ–¼ä»æœªè­‰å¾—è€…ï¼Œæ‡‰ç•¶æŒçºŒä¿®è¡Œï¼Œç›´åˆ°ç©¶ç«Ÿæ­¢æ¯è™•ã€‚

ä¸Šè¿°å››å€‹æå•ï¼Œçš†ç‚ºå¾éŒ¯èª¤è§€é»å‡ºç™¼ã€‚
å…©ä½é˜¿ç¾…æ¼¢å·²ç‚ºæˆ‘å€‘ç¢ºå®šç­”æ¡ˆï¼š

è‹¥æˆ²è«–æ»…ï¼Œå³æ˜¯æ¶…æ§ƒï¼›è‹¥æœªæ»…ï¼Œäº”è˜Šå°‡å†ç”Ÿã€‚

æƒ³çµæŸè‹¦ï¼Œå¿…é ˆæ–·æˆ²è«–ä¹‹å› ï¼š

æ­¤ã€Œå› ã€å³æ˜¯ã€Œå¿ƒï¼ˆviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aï¼‰ã€æˆ–ã€Œæ„æ ¹ï¼ˆmanÄyatanaï¼‰ã€ã€‚

ã€å°Šè€…å†æ¬¡æ•™å°ã€Œè§€å¿ƒæ³•ã€ã€‘ï¼š

è¼ªè¿´çš„å»¶ä¼¸

ä¸€ä¹å…­äºŒå¹´äº”æœˆåäº”æ—¥

[è²ªæ„›ã€æ…¢å¿ƒå’Œé‚ªè¦‹æ˜¯å»¶ä¼¸è¼ªè¿´ï¼ˆç”Ÿæ­»è¼ªè¿´ï¼‰çš„æ³•ã€‚å…«è–é“æ˜¯æ–·é™¤è¼ªè¿´çš„æ³•ã€‚æ‘©è¨¶æ‹˜çµºç¾…å°Šè€…å’Œèˆåˆ©å¼—å°Šè€…ä¹‹é–“çš„å•ç­”å°±æ˜¯é—œæ–¼é€™äº›æ³•ã€‚æ‘©è¨¶æ‹˜çµºç¾…å°Šè€…æå•ï¼Œèˆåˆ©å¼—å°Šè€…å›ç­”ã€‚

  1. å•ï¼šå…­è™•ï¼ˆå…­æ ¹è™•ï¼‰æ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œé‚„æœ‰ä»€éº¼æœƒç”Ÿèµ·å—ï¼Ÿï¼ˆå³ï¼Œä»¥å¸¸è¦‹æå•ï¼‰ ç­”ï¼šä¸è¦é€™æ¨£å•ã€‚

  2. å•ï¼šå…­è™•æ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œæ²’æœ‰ä»€éº¼æœƒç”Ÿèµ·å—ï¼Ÿï¼ˆä»¥æ–·è¦‹æå•ï¼‰ ç­”ï¼šä¸è¦é€™æ¨£å•ã€‚

ç¬¬ä¸‰å’Œç¬¬å››å€‹å•é¡Œæ˜¯ä»¥éƒ¨åˆ†å¸¸è¦‹å’Œä¸æ­»æˆ²è«–è¦‹çš„é‚ªè¦‹æå•ã€‚ ç­”æ¡ˆç›¸åŒã€‚

è¥¿äºå¤šèªªï¼Œé€™äº›æ˜¯é—œæ–¼å/è‰²éç¨‹ã€‚ä»–ç”¨å¿ƒçš„è§€ç…§ï¼ˆcittÄnupassanÄï¼‰ä¾†è§£é‡‹å®ƒå€‘ã€‚å¿ƒæ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œæ¶…æ§ƒé¡¯ç¾ï¼›å› æ­¤ï¼Œå…­è™•æ­¢æ¯å¾Œå°±æ˜¯æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚æ‘©è¨¶æ‹˜çµºç¾…å°Šè€…å•çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œæœ‰ä»€éº¼ç™¼ç”Ÿçš„æ„æ€æ˜¯æŒ‡çœ¾ç”Ÿæˆ–æˆ²è«–ï¼ˆprapaÃ±caï¼Œå³è²ªæ„›ã€æ…¢å¿ƒå’Œé‚ªè¦‹ï¼‰ã€‚æˆ²è«–æ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œç„¡æˆ²è«–ï¼ˆni-prapaÃ±caï¼‰ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆæ²’æœ‰æˆ²è«–å°±æ˜¯æ¶…æ§ƒï¼‰ã€‚

è¥¿äºå¤šçµ¦äº†ä¸€å€‹éå¸¸ç°¡å–®çš„æ¯—å©†èˆé‚£æŒ‡å°ã€‚ç„¡è«–ä»€éº¼å¿ƒç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œéƒ½è¦è§€å¯Ÿå®ƒçš„ç„¡å¸¸ã€‚ç”¨ç¬¬äºŒå€‹å¿ƒè§€å¯Ÿç¬¬ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒï¼›ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒæ˜¯ç”Ÿèµ·çš„æ³•ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒå€‹å¿ƒæ˜¯è§€å¯Ÿçš„å¿ƒã€‚ä½ å€‘æœƒçœ‹åˆ°ç„¡å¸¸ã€‚å…©å€‹å¿ƒä¸èƒ½åŒæ™‚ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚åœ¨å…­è™•ä¸­ï¼Œæ„è™•ï¼ˆmanÄyatanaï¼‰æ˜¯æˆ²è«–æ³•ç”Ÿèµ·çš„åœ°æ–¹ã€‚]

åœ¨äº”è˜Šä¸­ï¼Œæœ‰å…©ç¨®æ³•ã€‚å»¶ä¼¸è‹¦çš„æ³•å’Œä¸å»¶ä¼¸è‹¦çš„æ³•ã€‚çŸ¥é“é€™å€‹äº”è˜Šæ˜¯è‹¦çš„äººï¼Œä¸æœƒå»¶ä¼¸è‹¦ã€‚è‹¦èˆ‡è‹¦ç›¸é€£ä¸¦æŒçºŒä¸‹å»ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯æˆ²è«–æ³•ã€‚æ­»äº¡èˆ‡å‡ºç”Ÿç›¸é€£ï¼Œå…©è€…éƒ½æ˜¯è‹¦ï¼ˆcuti â†’ jÄtiï¼‰ã€‚ä¸å»¶ä¼¸è‹¦çš„æ³•æ˜¯ç„¡æˆ²è«–æ³•ï¼ˆæ²’æœ‰æˆ²è«–ï¼‰ã€‚

è‹¥ä½ å€‘æƒ³çµæŸè‹¦ï¼Œå¿…é ˆä¿®è¡Œä¸¦åœæ­¢æˆ²è«–æ³•çš„ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚ä½ å€‘éƒ½æœ‰å¾ˆå¤šå»¶ä¼¸çš„æ³•ã€‚è¦æ”¾æ£„å®ƒå€‘ï¼Œä½ å€‘éœ€è¦è€å¸«çš„å¹«åŠ©ã€‚ä½ å€‘ä¹Ÿå¿…é ˆåŠªåŠ›ä¿®è¡Œã€‚å»¶ä¼¸çš„æ³•æ˜¯è²ªæ„›ã€æ…¢å¿ƒå’Œé‚ªè¦‹ã€‚

ä¸å»¶ä¼¸çš„æ³•æ˜¯é“æ”¯ã€‚å®ƒå€‘éƒ½å¾å¿ƒä¸­ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚æ”¾æ£„å®ƒå€‘çš„æ³•åªå­˜åœ¨æ–¼ä½›é™€çš„æ•™å°ä¸­ã€‚å»¶ä¼¸çš„æ³•ä¸€ç›´å­˜åœ¨ã€‚ï¼ˆæ‰€æœ‰å…¶ä»–æ•™å°ä¹‹å¤–çš„ç³»çµ±å’ŒçŸ¥è­˜ï¼‰ã€‚ä»€éº¼å»¶ä¼¸å®ƒå€‘ï¼Œå¿…é ˆè¢«æ”¾æ£„ï¼Ÿé€™å€‹å•é¡Œç”¢ç”Ÿäº†ã€‚ï¼ˆè¥¿äºå¤šè¬›è¿°äº†æ‘©è¨¶æ‹˜çµºç¾…å°Šè€…å’Œèˆåˆ©å¼—å°Šè€…ä¹‹é–“çš„å•ç­”ï¼‰

è‹¥å…­è™•æ­¢æ¯ï¼›é‚„æœ‰å…¶ä»–ç…©æƒ±ç”Ÿèµ·å—ï¼Ÿç­”æ¡ˆæ˜¯ä¸æ‡‰è©²é€™æ¨£å•ã€‚çœ¼è™•ï¼ˆcakkhÄyatanaï¼‰åˆ°èº«è™•ï¼ˆkayÄyatanaï¼‰æ˜¯äº”è‰²è™•ï¼ˆçœ¼ã€è€³ã€é¼»ã€èˆŒã€èº«ï¼‰ã€‚æ„è™•ï¼ˆmanÄyatanaï¼‰åªæœ‰ä¸€å€‹ã€‚å°‡å®ƒå€‘ç›¸åŠ ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯å…­æ ¹è™•ã€‚

å®ƒå€‘æ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œé‚„æœ‰å…¶ä»–ç…©æƒ±ç”Ÿèµ·å—ï¼Ÿæˆ–è€…æœ‰ä»€éº¼å­˜åœ¨å—ï¼Ÿä¸è¦é€™æ¨£å•ã€‚åœ¨æ­¢æ¯çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œæ¶…æ§ƒå¿…å®šé¡¯ç¾ã€‚é€éé€™å…­è™•ï¼Œæ³•å¯ä»¥åˆ°é”æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚èˆåˆ©å¼—å°Šè€…è«‡è«–çš„æ˜¯è§€ç…§å…­è™•çš„ç„¡å¸¸ã€‚å®ƒåŒ…æ‹¬èº«è§€ç…§å’Œå¿ƒè§€ç…§ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰å¿ƒæ­¢æ¯ï¼Œæ²’æœ‰ä»€éº¼ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œåªæœ‰æ¶…æ§ƒé¡¯ç¾ã€‚é€™æ—¢ä¸æ˜¯äººä¹Ÿä¸æ˜¯çœ¾ç”Ÿã€‚æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œä½ å€‘ä¸éœ€è¦å•ï¼›æœ‰ä»€éº¼ç”Ÿèµ·å—ï¼Ÿæ²’æœ‰æˆ²è«–ï¼Œé€™èˆ‡å•ï¼›æœ‰æˆ²è«–å—ï¼Ÿç›¸åŒã€‚è‹¥æˆ²è«–æ­¢æ¯ï¼Œæ¶…æ§ƒå°±æœƒé¡¯ç¾ã€‚ä¸è¦å°æ­¤æœ‰ä»»ä½•æ‡·ç–‘ã€‚é‚„æ²’æœ‰çµæŸçš„äººï¼Œå¿…é ˆå …æŒåˆ°åº•ã€‚

æ‰€æœ‰å››å€‹å•é¡Œéƒ½æ˜¯ç”¨é‚ªè¦‹æå•çš„ã€‚å…©ä½é˜¿ç¾…æ¼¢éƒ½åœ¨ç‚ºæˆ‘å€‘åšæ±ºå®šã€‚è‹¥æˆ²è«–æ­¢æ¯ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯æ¶…æ§ƒï¼Œè‹¥ä¸æ­¢æ¯ï¼Œäº”è˜Šå°±æœƒç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚è‹¥æƒ³çµæŸè‹¦ï¼Œä½ å€‘å¿…é ˆæ¶ˆæ»…æˆ²è«–çš„èµ·å› ã€‚å®ƒæ˜¯å¿ƒæˆ–æ„è™•ã€‚ï¼ˆè¥¿äºå¤šç¹¼çºŒæ•™å°å¿ƒçš„è§€ç…§ã€‚ï¼‰

å¿ƒæ˜¯è­˜è˜Šã€‚ç”¨ç¬¬äºŒå€‹å¿ƒè§€ç…§ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒã€‚æ¯æ¬¡ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œéƒ½ç”¨ç¬¬äºŒå€‹å¿ƒè§€ç…§ã€‚ä½ å€‘çŸ¥é“å®ƒä¸å­˜åœ¨ã€‚ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œç”¨ç¬¬äºŒå€‹å¿ƒè·Ÿéš¨ï¼Œæˆ²è«–å°±æœƒæ­¢æ¯ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæƒ³åƒæ±è¥¿çš„å¿ƒç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œä½ å€‘ä¹‹å¾Œè§€ç…§ï¼Œå®ƒé‚„åœ¨å—ï¼Ÿ

å…©å€‹å¿ƒä¸èƒ½åŒæ™‚ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚å‰ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒæ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œå¾Œä¸€å€‹å¿ƒæ‰èƒ½ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚ç”Ÿèµ·çš„å¿ƒæ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒã€‚ä¸å­˜åœ¨çš„å¿ƒæ˜¯ç¬¬äºŒå€‹å¿ƒã€‚ç”¨ç¬¬äºŒå€‹å¿ƒè·Ÿéš¨ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒå°±è¶³å¤ äº†ã€‚ï¼ˆåªæœ‰ç”Ÿèµ·çš„å¿ƒæ¶ˆå¤±ï¼Œè§€å¯Ÿçš„å¿ƒæ‰èƒ½å–ä»£å®ƒçš„ä½ç½®ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œè§€å¯Ÿçš„å¿ƒçœ‹åˆ°å®ƒä¸å­˜åœ¨ã€‚é€™å°±æ˜¯çœ‹è¦‹ç©ºã€‚ï¼‰

ç”¨å¾Œé¢çš„çŸ¥å¿ƒï¼ˆå³é“æ”¯å¿ƒæˆ–è§€ç…§å¿ƒï¼‰è§€ç…§å‰é¢çš„å¿ƒã€‚å‰é¢çš„å¿ƒç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œç”¨å¾Œé¢çš„å¿ƒè·Ÿéš¨ã€‚ç„¶å¾Œæˆ²è«–æ¶ˆå¤±ï¼Œä¸å†ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚èˆ‰å€‹ä¾‹å­ï¼Œåœ¨è›‡å‡ºæ²’çš„åœ°å€ï¼Œä½ å€‘é¤Šä¸€éš»è²“é¼¬ï¼Œè›‡å°±æœƒæ¶ˆå¤±ï¼Œä¸å†ä¾†ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ”¾æ£„æˆ²è«–æ˜¯æ¸…æ¥šçš„ã€‚ï¼ˆè¥¿äºå¤šç¹¼çºŒè§£é‡‹çœ‹è¦‹ç„¡å¸¸ã€å­é›¢å’Œæ­¢æ¯çš„å…§è§€éç¨‹ã€‚ï¼‰ä¸è¦å®³æ€•å‡ºç”Ÿï¼ˆjÄtiï¼‰ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯è¦å®³æ€•æˆ²è«–æ³•ã€‚å› ç‚ºå‡ºç”Ÿæ˜¯çµæœï¼Œæˆ²è«–æ˜¯å…¶åŸå› ã€‚è‹¦æ¶ˆå¤±ï¼Œæ¨‚ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚å…‰æ˜é¡¯ç¾ï¼Œé»‘æš—æ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚


With Kilesa Sap, No Real Happiness



29th May 1962


[Based on a sutta named "The Milk Sap Tree" from the Saá¸·Äyatanasaá¹ƒyutta (SN.35.231 KhÄ«rarukkhopamasuttaá¹ƒ). The Buddha compared kilesa (defilements) with sticky sap from a banyan tree. The six sensesâ€bases are like a tree with sticky sap latent with the kilesas of lobha, dosa, and moha.


The six senseâ€objects are like knifes (in the sutta was axe). It contacts with the six sensesâ€bases and latent kilesas flow out. The Buddha used a lot of similes, metaphors, examples from nature to teach the Dhamma. Sometimes it was quite amazing and profound. Human beings are part of nature. We are under the same natural laws.


If we can observe and contemplate, even nature becomes our great teacher. Sayadawâ€™s talk was quite humorous. Some of his talks were mentioned human stupidity in a humorous and profound ways.]


Human beings have kilesa saps (even may be like a superâ€glue). Itâ€™s like a banyan or fig tree and cut with a knife and the saps flow out. In the same way, senseâ€objects contact with senseâ€bases and kilesa saps flowing out.


(For example, Sayadaw mentioned many things in daily life). It is immeasurable or uncountable times that kilesa saps are flowing out from the khandha because we are cutting it with the knives of senseâ€objects. There are six knives. Cutting by these knives is only one tree. Itâ€™s the tree of khandha. After the saps are flowing out and the tree dies out.


Every day I am giving talk is to make your kilesa sap becomes dry up. The six knives are the six sensesâ€objects. The tree is the khandha. The sap is kilesa. Every time the saps flow out and make the tree to die. A good and holy person or not, has to decide with the sap comes out or not.


The reason you all donâ€™t realize NibbÄna are the sap flows out continuously to connect life again and again. You all are happy with places making your saps flow out. If not flowing out and you take it as quite boring. D. A. process starts from where the sap flows out. When a person is getting old and has more knowledge. These more knowledge are making your saps flowing out. You all know how to make the saps come out. But donâ€™t know how to stop it. You become bored without it.


If youâ€™re not connecting saá¹sÄra and life becomes very dry. The work of drying up the sap is the only truly reliable thing to do. It is these kilesa saps that causes this tree to die and produce another tree. If the sap begins to flow, itâ€™s the dukkha arising (dukkha samudayo hoti)â€”so it is the cause of the dukkha.


If it continues to flow out is dukkha khandhassa hotiâ€”the result of dukkha. Your khandhas have 1,500 kilesa saps. So it needs a lot of work to burn it. Ordinary kind of fire canâ€™t do the job. You have to burn it with the maggin fire (the path fire) as strong as the hell fire.


Except the path fire, there is no other thing to rely on. For the Buddha and arahants, even they encountered with the worldly dhamma and no saps to flow out. Because they had already dried it up with the path fire.


æœ‰ç…©æƒ±è† æ±ï¼Œç„¡çœŸæ­£å¿«æ¨‚

1962å¹´5æœˆ29æ—¥é–‹ç¤º
ï¼ˆä¾æ“šã€Šç›¸æ‡‰éƒ¨ï¼å…­è™•ç›¸æ‡‰ã€‹ä¸­çš„ã€Šä¹³æ¨¹å–»ç¶“ã€‹ï¼ˆSN 35.231 KhÄ«rarukkhopamasuttaá¹ƒï¼‰ï¼‰

ä½›é™€ä»¥ã€Œç…©æƒ±ï¼ˆkilesaï¼‰å¦‚åŒæ¦•æ¨¹çš„é»è† ä¹³æ±ã€ç‚ºè­¬å–»ï¼Œä¾†èªªæ˜çœ¾ç”Ÿç‚ºä½•é›£å¾—è§£è„«ã€‚

ç¶“ä¸­è­¬å–»ï¼š

  • å…­æ ¹ï¼ˆå…­è™• Äyatanaï¼‰ï¼šå¦‚åŒä¸€æ£µå……æ»¿è† æ±çš„å¤§æ¨¹ï¼ˆå¦‚æ¦•æ¨¹æˆ–ç„¡èŠ±æœæ¨¹ï¼‰

  • å…­å¡µï¼ˆå…­å¢ƒ sense objectsï¼‰ï¼šå¦‚åŒå…­æŠŠé‹’åˆ©çš„åˆ€ï¼ˆç¶“ä¸­ç‚ºæ–§é ­ï¼‰

  • ç…©æƒ±ï¼ˆkilesaï¼‰ï¼šæ˜¯æ¨¹ä¸­æ‰€è—çš„è† æ±ï¼ˆsapï¼‰

ç•¶å…­å¡µæ¥è§¸å…­æ ¹æ™‚ï¼Œä¾¿å¦‚åˆ€æ–¬æ¨¹ï¼Œä»¤è† æ±ï¼ˆç…©æƒ±ï¼‰æ¹§å‡ºã€‚

ä½›é™€ç¶“å¸¸ä»¥è‡ªç„¶ç•Œçš„æ¯”å–»ä¾†æ•™å°æ³•ç¾©ï¼Œæ·±å…¥è€Œå¯Œæœ‰æ™ºæ…§ï¼Œå› ç‚ºï¼š

äººäº¦å±¬è‡ªç„¶ä¹‹ç‰©ï¼Œå—è‡ªç„¶æ³•å‰‡æ‰€åˆ¶ã€‚
è‹¥æˆ‘å€‘èƒ½è§€å¯Ÿã€æ€æƒŸï¼Œè‡ªç„¶äº¦èƒ½æˆç‚ºæœ€å¥½çš„å°å¸«ã€‚

å°Šè€…é€™å ´é–‹ç¤ºæ—¢æ·±åˆ»åˆå¸¶é»å¹½é»˜ï¼š

ã€Œäººé¡çš„æ„šç™¡ï¼Œæœ‰æ™‚çœŸè®“äººå“­ç¬‘ä¸å¾—ã€‚ã€

å¦‚ä»Šäººé¡çš„èº«å¿ƒï¼Œå°±å¦‚åŒå……æ»¿è¶…é»æ€§è† æ±çš„æ¨¹ï¼ˆæ¯”è¶…èƒ½è† é‚„å¼·ï¼‰ã€‚
ç•¶æ„Ÿå®˜æ¥è§¸å¢ƒç•Œæ™‚ï¼Œç…©æƒ±çš„æ±æ¶²å³åˆ»æ¹§å‡ºã€‚

å°Šè€…èˆ‰äº†è¨±å¤šç”Ÿæ´»ä¸­çš„ä¾‹å­ä¾†èªªæ˜ï¼Œé€™äº›è† æ±å¹¾ä¹å¤©å¤©ã€ç„¡æ•¸æ¬¡åœ°å¾ã€Œäº”è˜Šä¹‹æ¨¹ã€æµå‡ºä¾†ã€‚

å…­æŠŠåˆ€ä¸åœç è‘—åŒä¸€æ£µæ¨¹â€”â€”é€™æ£µæ¨¹å³æ˜¯ä½ çš„èº«å¿ƒï¼ˆkhandhaï¼‰ã€‚
è€Œç•¶è† æ±æµå‡ºï¼Œå°±æ˜¯ã€Œç…©æƒ±ç¾èµ·ã€ï¼Œä¹…è€Œä¹…ä¹‹ï¼Œé€™æ£µæ¨¹ï¼ˆèº«å¿ƒï¼‰ä¾¿æ­»äº¡ã€åˆå†ç”Ÿä¸€æ£µæ–°çš„æ¨¹ï¼ˆè¼ªè¿´å†èµ·ï¼‰ã€‚

æˆ‘æ¯æ—¥ç‚ºä½ å€‘é–‹ç¤ºçš„ç›®çš„ï¼Œ
å°±æ˜¯ç‚ºäº†è®“ä½ å€‘çš„ã€Œç…©æƒ±è† æ±ä¹¾æ¯ã€ã€‚

æ¯ç•¶è† æ±æµå‡ºä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯ç”Ÿæ­»å»¶çºŒä¸€æ¬¡ã€‚

è¦åˆ¤æ–·ä¸€äººæ˜¯å¦ã€Œè–è€…ï¼ˆholy personï¼‰ã€æˆ–ã€Œå‡¡å¤«ã€ï¼Œå¯è§€å…¶ã€Œè† æ±æ˜¯å¦ç¹¼çºŒæµå‡ºã€ã€‚

ä½ å€‘ä¹‹æ‰€ä»¥ç„¡æ³•è­‰å¾—æ¶…æ§ƒï¼Œæ˜¯å› ç‚ºé€™äº›æ±æ¶²ä¸æ–·åœ°æµå‡ºï¼Œå°‡ã€Œç”Ÿå‘½ã€ä¸€æ¬¡åˆä¸€æ¬¡åœ°é€£æ¥ä¸‹å»ã€‚

ç”šè‡³ï¼Œä½ å€‘é‚„å–œæ­¡é‚£äº›ä»¤è† æ±æµå‡ºçš„ç’°å¢ƒèˆ‡å ´æ‰€ï¼Œ
è‹¥è† æ±ä¸æµå‡ºï¼Œåè€Œè¦ºå¾—ç„¡èŠã€‚

ç·£èµ·éˆï¼ˆD.A. processï¼‰ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯å¾è† æ±é–‹å§‹æµå‡ºçš„åœ°æ–¹èµ·å§‹ã€‚

æœ‰äº›äººå¹´ç´€è¶Šå¤§ï¼Œæ‰€è¬‚çš„ã€ŒçŸ¥è­˜ã€è¶Šå¤šï¼Œå»æ˜¯è®“ç…©æƒ±æ±æµå¾—æ›´å‡¶ã€‚

ä¸€ä¹å…­äºŒå¹´äº”æœˆäºŒåä¹æ—¥

[åŸºæ–¼ã€Šç›¸æ‡‰éƒ¨ã€‹ï¼ˆSaá¸·Äyatanasaá¹ƒyuttaï¼‰ä¸­çš„ã€Šä¹³æ±æ¨¹ç¶“ã€‹ï¼ˆSN.35.231 KhÄ«rarukkhopamasuttaá¹ƒï¼‰ã€‚ä½›é™€å°‡ç…©æƒ±ï¼ˆkilesaï¼‰æ¯”ä½œæ¦•æ¨¹çš„é»ç¨ æ±æ¶²ã€‚å…­æ ¹è™•å°±åƒä¸€æ£µæ½›è—è‘—è²ªã€ç‹ã€ç™¡ç…©æƒ±çš„æ¨¹ã€‚

å…­æ ¹å¢ƒå°±åƒåˆ€å­ï¼ˆç¶“ä¸­æ˜¯æ–§é ­ï¼‰ã€‚å®ƒèˆ‡å…­æ ¹è™•æ¥è§¸ï¼Œæ½›è—çš„ç…©æƒ±å°±æœƒæµå‡ºã€‚ä½›é™€ç”¨äº†å¾ˆå¤šä¾†è‡ªå¤§è‡ªç„¶çš„è­¬å–»ã€æ¯”å–»å’Œä¾‹å­ä¾†æ•™å°ä½›æ³•ã€‚æœ‰æ™‚å®ƒéå¸¸ä»¤äººé©šå˜†å’Œæ·±åˆ»ã€‚äººé¡æ˜¯å¤§è‡ªç„¶çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚æˆ‘å€‘è™•æ–¼ç›¸åŒçš„è‡ªç„¶æ³•å‰‡ä¹‹ä¸‹ã€‚

è‹¥æˆ‘å€‘èƒ½å¤ è§€å¯Ÿå’Œè§€ç…§ï¼Œå³ä½¿å¤§è‡ªç„¶ä¹Ÿæœƒæˆç‚ºæˆ‘å€‘å‰å¤§çš„è€å¸«ã€‚è¥¿äºå¤šçš„é–‹ç¤ºéå¸¸å¹½é»˜ã€‚ä»–çš„ä¸€äº›é–‹ç¤ºä»¥å¹½é»˜è€Œæ·±åˆ»çš„æ–¹å¼æåˆ°äº†äººé¡çš„æ„šè ¢ã€‚]

äººé¡æœ‰ç…©æƒ±ä¹‹æ±ï¼ˆç”šè‡³å¯èƒ½åƒå¼·åŠ›è† ï¼‰ã€‚å®ƒå°±åƒä¸€æ£µæ¦•æ¨¹æˆ–ç„¡èŠ±æœæ¨¹ï¼Œç”¨åˆ€å­åˆ‡å‰²ï¼Œæ±æ¶²å°±æœƒæµå‡ºã€‚åŒæ¨£åœ°ï¼Œæ ¹å¢ƒèˆ‡æ ¹è™•æ¥è§¸ï¼Œç…©æƒ±ä¹‹æ±å°±æœƒæµå‡ºã€‚

ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œè¥¿äºå¤šæåˆ°äº†æ—¥å¸¸ç”Ÿæ´»ä¸­çš„è¨±å¤šäº‹æƒ…ï¼‰ã€‚ç…©æƒ±ä¹‹æ±å¾äº”è˜Šæµå‡ºçš„æ¬¡æ•¸æ˜¯ä¸å¯è¡¡é‡æˆ–ä¸å¯è¨ˆæ•¸çš„ï¼Œå› ç‚ºæˆ‘å€‘ç”¨æ ¹å¢ƒçš„åˆ€å­åˆ‡å‰²å®ƒã€‚æœ‰å…­æŠŠåˆ€å­ã€‚ç”¨é€™äº›åˆ€å­åˆ‡å‰²çš„åªæ˜¯ä¸€æ£µæ¨¹ã€‚å®ƒæ˜¯äº”è˜Šä¹‹æ¨¹ã€‚æ±æ¶²æµå‡ºå¾Œï¼Œæ¨¹å°±æœƒæ¯æ­»ã€‚

æˆ‘æ¯å¤©çš„é–‹ç¤ºéƒ½æ˜¯ç‚ºäº†ä½¿ä½ å€‘çš„ç…©æƒ±ä¹‹æ±è®Šä¹¾ã€‚ä¸€å€‹äººæ˜¯å¥½äººé‚„æ˜¯è–æ½”çš„äººï¼Œéƒ½å¿…é ˆæ ¹æ“šæ±æ¶²æ˜¯å¦æµå‡ºä¾†æ±ºå®šã€‚

ä½ å€‘éƒ½ç„¡æ³•è­‰å¾—æ¶…æ§ƒçš„åŸå› æ˜¯ï¼Œæ±æ¶²ä¸æ–·æµå‡ºï¼Œä¸€æ¬¡åˆä¸€æ¬¡åœ°é€£æ¥ç”Ÿå‘½ã€‚ä½ å€‘éƒ½å°ä½¿ä½ å€‘çš„æ±æ¶²æµå‡ºçš„åœ°æ–¹æ„Ÿåˆ°å¿«æ¨‚ã€‚è‹¥ä¸æµå‡ºï¼Œä½ å€‘æœƒèªç‚ºå®ƒéå¸¸ç„¡èŠã€‚ç·£èµ·ï¼ˆD.A.ï¼‰éç¨‹å¾æ±æ¶²æµå‡ºçš„åœ°æ–¹é–‹å§‹ã€‚ç•¶ä¸€å€‹äººè®Šè€ä¸¦æ“æœ‰æ›´å¤šçŸ¥è­˜æ™‚ã€‚é€™äº›æ›´å¤šçš„çŸ¥è­˜æœƒä½¿ä½ å€‘çš„æ±æ¶²æµå‡ºã€‚ä½ å€‘éƒ½çŸ¥é“å¦‚ä½•ä½¿æ±æ¶²æµå‡ºã€‚ä½†ä¸çŸ¥é“å¦‚ä½•é˜»æ­¢å®ƒã€‚è‹¥æ²’æœ‰å®ƒï¼Œä½ å€‘æœƒæ„Ÿåˆ°ç„¡èŠã€‚

è‹¥ä½ å€‘ä¸é€£æ¥è¼ªè¿´ï¼Œç”Ÿå‘½å°±æœƒè®Šå¾—éå¸¸æ¯ç‡¥ã€‚ä½¿æ±æ¶²è®Šä¹¾çš„å·¥ä½œæ˜¯å”¯ä¸€çœŸæ­£å¯é çš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚æ­£æ˜¯é€™äº›ç…©æƒ±ä¹‹æ±å°è‡´é€™æ£µæ¨¹æ­»äº¡ä¸¦ç”¢ç”Ÿå¦ä¸€æ£µæ¨¹ã€‚è‹¥æ±æ¶²é–‹å§‹æµå‹•ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯è‹¦çš„ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆdukkha samudayo hotiï¼‰â€”â€”å› æ­¤å®ƒæ˜¯è‹¦çš„åŸå› ã€‚

è‹¥å®ƒç¹¼çºŒæµå‡ºï¼Œå°±æ˜¯è‹¦çš„çµæœï¼ˆdukkha khandhassa hotiï¼‰ã€‚ä½ å€‘çš„äº”è˜Šæœ‰1,500ç¨®ç…©æƒ±ä¹‹æ±ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œéœ€è¦å¤§é‡çš„å·¥ä½œä¾†ç‡ƒç‡’å®ƒã€‚æ™®é€šçš„ç«ç„¡æ³•å®Œæˆé€™é …å·¥ä½œã€‚ä½ å€‘å¿…é ˆç”¨åƒåœ°ç„ä¹‹ç«ä¸€æ¨£å¼·çƒˆçš„é“ç«ï¼ˆmaggin fireï¼Œpath fireï¼‰ç‡ƒç‡’å®ƒã€‚

é™¤äº†é“ç«ä¹‹å¤–ï¼Œæ²’æœ‰å…¶ä»–å¯ä»¥ä¾é çš„æ±è¥¿ã€‚å°æ–¼ä½›é™€å’Œé˜¿ç¾…æ¼¢ä¾†èªªï¼Œå³ä½¿ä»–å€‘é‡åˆ°ä¸–é–“æ³•ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ²’æœ‰æ±æ¶²æµå‡ºã€‚å› ç‚ºä»–å€‘å·²ç¶“ç”¨é“ç«å°‡å…¶ç‡’ä¹¾ã€‚


Unwise Attention and Prayers



4th June 1962


[This was a heart touching talk by Sayadaw because he knew himself would pass away very soon. Within three months most of his talks during these periods was at Mogok and also his last visit. He urged and encouraged his disciples with great compassion and concern for their practices. Gave a lot of saá¹vega talks here. In this talk oneâ€™s really feel his compassion and metta even it makes the listeners become sad.


He said, we were born and had the chances to free ourselves from dukkha because of the Dhamma. But what were we doing? Mostly for worldly concerns and it was adhamma (not Buddha Dhamma). He warned them the Buddhaâ€™s words. Once the Buddha took a few pieces of earth placed on his finger nail and said to the monks. If these pieces of earth fell to the ground and it would never get back on the nail.


In the same way, if a human being fell into dugati (painful birth) would difficult to get back sugati (blissful birth). He mentioned another simile of a blind turtle living under a deep ocean and a yoke with a hole floating in the ocean. This blind turtle every hundred years emerged once on to the surface.


It was moving blindly in the very wide ocean. The yoke with the hole was also moving randomly in the ocean. After a very long period of time accidentally the blind turtle head could enter into its hole. But, once a human being fell into dugati emerged from there was more difficult than the blind turtle head entered in to the hole.


Sayadaw based this talk from the BhÅ«mija Sutta of the Majjhima NikÄya (MN.126 BhÅ«mijasuttaá¹ƒ), a discussion between Ven. BhÅ«mija and Prince Jayasena (uncle and nephew). Jayasena asked four questions to Ven. BhÅ«mija. It becomes two questions combining those four together.


Q1: Some yogis are making prayers and practice but canâ€™t realize NibbÄna.

Q2: Some yogis are not making prayers and only practice but canâ€™t realize NibbÄna.


What is the Buddhaâ€™s view on these questions? Ven. BhÅ«mija answered that he never heard the Buddha mentioned on these questions, but he could give his views. He said both of the problems were based on unwise attention (ayoniso) that couldnâ€™t realize NibbÄna. Jayasena requested him to ask the Buddha for the answers.


Ven. BhÅ«mija went to see the Buddha and presented the questions. The Buddha gave the simile of putting sands into the grinding tool and prayed for oil but would never get oil because the methods was not right. If you put sesame seeds and even without the prayers and would get oil because the method was right. So in vipassanÄ practice yoniso is very important, and it needs a teacherâ€™s help.


Sayadaw gave a simple instruction for vipassanÄ. At first, calm the mind down by knowing the breath going in and out from the nostril. After sometime the mind calms down. The body will show its nature with the sensations. He gave the example: a small lizard fell on to the floor from a high ceiling at a quiet midnight. It would make a loud noise which everyone could hear.


But, in the day time with noises around would no one aware of it. In the same way yogi has samÄdhi will know whatever the body shows its nature. It shows its changing nature. Before samÄdhi, it also has this nature. But, after samÄdhi see it clear. Therefore, the Buddha taught on samÄdhi in many suttas (For example, in Aá¹…guttara NikÄya).


Someone has samÄdhi and knows the true nature of the khandha. If the body is itching, aching, paining, etc. are vedanÄkkhandha. Different kinds of mind arise and also know it. Know the form (rÅ«pa) of heat and cold. The arising is changing, and the perishing is disappearing. Only impermanence exists. Not a man nor a woman and not me and not him, khandha disappears. Only seeing the arising and passing away.


Vipariá¹‡Äma lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ dukkha saccaá¹â€”Disbanding its own nature is truth of dukkha. The changing and perishing are dukkha sacca. At the time of seeing impermanence, you donâ€™t need to distinguish them as mind and body. This is seeing the truth of dhammÄnupassanÄ, the Contemplation of Dhamma. This is seeing the truth of dukkha sacca and seeing is magga sacca.


Then you get the eye of right viewâ€”sammÄâ€diá¹­á¹­hi eye. (From here to NibbÄna Sayadaw mentioned quite a lot of things). He gave a simile of how NibbÄna appears. Like a movie screen many pictures arise and cease, arise and cease, etc. After the movie ends the white screen appears. In the same way NibbÄna appears. Khandha arises and ceases, arises and ceases, etc. After aniccas end and everything is clear up.]


If you live in the adhamma way D. A. process continues (adhammaâ€”not the way of Dhamma. Here Dhamma means in accordance with the Buddhaâ€™s Dhamma). And live with Dhamma and the D. A. process is cutting off. Now, with this adhamma of dosa is following with sorrow (soka) (For example: This is the moment when parents have displeasure with their children).


Children are not the problem, but parents are going to the apÄya (planes of misery). People not listening and practising Dhamma in this present life become adhamma. And they are going around among the woeful planes in saá¹sÄra. We arrived at this human world with wholesome dhammas. After arriving but doing adhamma, we will lose our capitals (i.e., our wholesome kammas become fruitless in this life).


The Buddha gave some similes for the loss (The similes of earth on the finger nail and a blind turtle in the ocean). So, the Buddha warned you on the value of your human life. From the human life you can go to NibbÄna and not from the apÄyabhÅ«mi (continued to talk the BhÅ«mija Sutta). The matter of realization of NibbÄna depends on wise/right attention. Originally nobody is right. It needs the help of a teacher. Itâ€™s a very important matter to have wise attention on the khandha.


(Gave vipassanÄ instruction) First establish samÄdhi for about 15 or 20 minutes. This is for the beginners. Someone who already discerns impermanence does not need to start from here. Know the touching of the every breath going in and out. After sometimes get samÄdhi and the mind doesnâ€™t run away and knowing continuously.


The mind becomes calm, just breathing in and out as usual. With samÄdhi, the body will tell you; itching, pain, numbness, hot, cold, etc. With samÄdhi whatever it tells you, donâ€™t you know it? (He gave the example of a lizard falls from a ceiling to the floor at a very quiet midnight).


The khandha nature appears in different ways. This is the khandha changing. Without samÄdhi the khandha is also changing, but we donâ€™t know it. Someone has samÄdhi knows the khandha as it really is. How to know it as really is? It's telling you as vedanÄkkhandha (feeling aggregate). Pain, feeling good and in between are also vedanÄkkhandha.


So, you know as in the khandha different kinds of feeling arise. Different types of mind arise. Form (rÅ«pa) are becoming hot and cold, calming and moving, the khandha will tell you in many different ways. The Buddha taught that khandha was changing (vipariá¹‡Äma). Now, the newly dhamma is arising by disbanding the old one. With samÄdhi and observe the arising and it disappears.


The changing is arising and its perishing is vanishing. So, always come back to arising and passing away. Therefore, in the khandha only exist with arising and passing away or changing and perishing. Itâ€™s neither a man nor a woman. Then no need to dispel wrong view. At that time you donâ€™t see any face. By looking at the changing and man and woman disappear. Man and woman are only in speech with the mouth.


After closing your five senseâ€doors and open your Ã±Äá¹‡a eye to observe. Vipariá¹‡Äma lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ dukkha saccaá¹â€”Disbanding its own nature is the characteristic of the truth of dukkha. It is changing and also disbanding its own nature. The perishing is also the same.


Therefore, all the changing and perishing are the truth of dukkha. At the time no need to differentiate them as mind and body. It becomes seeing the truth, DhammÄnupassanÄ Satipaá¹­á¹­hÄna. Changing and perishing are dukkha sacca and seeing or knowing is magga sacca.


At that time becomes right attention. Right attention is going with paÃ±Ã±Ä, the eye of right viewâ€”sammÄâ€diá¹­á¹­hi. Itâ€™s also the eye of knowledgeâ€”vijjÄ eye. In real, itâ€™s only one Ã±Äá¹‡a eye. Now, you get the eye of seeing dukkha. After that you must get the eye of seeing NibbÄna.


The changing and perishing are anicca, also dukkha and anatta. Only seeing the truth will see NibbÄna. Contemplation of impermanence is contemplation of truth. This is not the ways of sensual pleasure and selfâ€mortification. Itâ€™s the middle way. It arrives in the middle of taá¹‡hÄ and dosa. With time go on, Ã±Äá¹‡a become mature and disenchanted.


Why is that? Because you are getting the changing and perishing. It will develop into the knowledge of disenchantment (NibbidÄ Ã‘Äá¹‡a) if you are seeing it a lot. Before you are thinking is as get the proper thing. Later not only become disenchantment with it. But also develop into not wanting and getting of it.


When it happens and at the same time all the changing and perishing disappear. (i.e., khandha disappears). And itâ€™s turning towards NibbÄna. Not changing and perishing of the stable NibbÄna appears. (Sayadaw gave the simile of a movie show for the vipassanÄ process). Before it was untidy with impermanence and with NibbÄna appears it is clear away.


ä¸æ­£ç¢ºä½œæ„èˆ‡ç¥ˆé¡˜

1962å¹´6æœˆ4æ—¥é–‹ç¤º

é€™æ˜¯ä¸€å ´ä»¤äººå‹•å®¹çš„é–‹ç¤ºã€‚å°Šè€…çŸ¥é“è‡ªå·±å³å°‡åœ“å¯‚ï¼Œå› æ­¤åœ¨ç”Ÿå‘½æœ€å¾Œä¸‰å€‹æœˆå…§ï¼Œåœ¨çŒ›è²¢æ‰€è¬›çš„å¤šå ´é–‹ç¤ºä¸­ï¼Œå¸¸æ‡‡åˆ‡å®åš€å¼Ÿå­ç²¾å‹¤ä¿®è¡Œï¼Œå……æ»¿æ…ˆæ‚²èˆ‡ç„¡ç›¡é—œæ‡·ã€‚

ç¶“ä¸­äº‘ï¼š

Vipariá¹‡Äma lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ dukkha saccaá¹
ã€Œè®Šå£ç‚ºç›¸ï¼Œå³æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ã€‚ã€

é€™æ¨£çš„è§€çŸ¥å³æ˜¯ï¼š

å…¶å¯¦é€™æ˜¯åŒä¸€ã€Œæ…§çœ¼ï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡aï¼‰ã€ã€‚

ç”Ÿæ»… â†’ ç„¡å¸¸ â†’ è‹¦ â†’ ç„¡æˆ‘
â†’ å”¯æœ‰è¦‹å¯¦ç›¸ï¼Œæ‰èƒ½è¦‹æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚

ç•¶è§€æ™ºæˆç†Ÿï¼Œç”Ÿèµ·å­é›¢ï¼ˆnibbidÄ Ã±Äá¹‡aï¼‰ï¼š

ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½


ä¸å¦‚ç†ä½œæ„èˆ‡ç¥ˆç¦±

ä¸€ä¹å…­äºŒå¹´å…­æœˆå››æ—¥

[é€™æ˜¯è¥¿äºå¤šä¸€æ¬¡ä»¤äººå‹•å®¹çš„é–‹ç¤ºï¼Œå› ç‚ºä»–çŸ¥é“è‡ªå·±å³å°‡åœ“å¯‚ã€‚åœ¨ä¸‰å€‹æœˆå…§ï¼Œä»–å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†çš„é–‹ç¤ºéƒ½æ˜¯åœ¨æŠ¹è°·ï¼Œé€™ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä»–æœ€å¾Œä¸€æ¬¡ä¾†è¨ªã€‚ä»–ä»¥æ¥µå¤§çš„æ…ˆæ‚²å’Œå°å¼Ÿå­ä¿®è¡Œçš„é—œæ‡·ï¼Œæ•¦ä¿ƒå’Œé¼“å‹µä»–å€‘ã€‚åœ¨é€™è£¡ï¼Œä»–çµ¦äºˆäº†å¾ˆå¤šä»¤äººæ„Ÿåˆ°æ‚šæ‡¼ï¼ˆsaá¹vegaï¼‰çš„é–‹ç¤ºã€‚åœ¨é€™æ¬¡é–‹ç¤ºä¸­ï¼Œäººå€‘çœŸæ­£æ„Ÿå—åˆ°ä»–çš„æ…ˆæ‚²å’Œæ…ˆæ„›ï¼Œç”šè‡³è®“è½çœ¾æ„Ÿåˆ°æ‚²å‚·ã€‚

ä»–èªªï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘å‡ºç”Ÿä¸¦æœ‰æ©Ÿæœƒå¾è‹¦ä¸­è§£è„«ï¼Œæ˜¯å› ç‚ºä½›æ³•ã€‚ä½†æˆ‘å€‘åœ¨åšä»€éº¼å‘¢ï¼Ÿå¤§éƒ¨åˆ†éƒ½æ˜¯ç‚ºäº†ä¸–ä¿—çš„é—œå¿ƒï¼Œé€™æ˜¯éæ³•ï¼ˆadhammaï¼Œéä½›é™€çš„æ•™å°ï¼‰ã€‚ä»–è­¦å‘Šä»–å€‘ä½›é™€çš„è©±ã€‚æœ‰ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œä½›é™€æ‹¿èµ·å¹¾å¡Šæ³¥åœŸæ”¾åœ¨æŒ‡ç”²ä¸Šï¼Œå°åƒ§ä¾¶å€‘èªªã€‚è‹¥é€™äº›æ³¥åœŸæ‰åˆ°åœ°ä¸Šï¼Œå°±æ°¸é ä¸æœƒå›åˆ°æŒ‡ç”²ä¸Šã€‚

åŒæ¨£åœ°ï¼Œè‹¥ä¸€å€‹äººå¢®å…¥æƒ¡é“ï¼ˆdugatiï¼Œç—›è‹¦çš„å‡ºç”Ÿï¼‰ï¼Œå°±å¾ˆé›£å›åˆ°å–„é“ï¼ˆsugatiï¼Œå¿«æ¨‚çš„å‡ºç”Ÿï¼‰ã€‚ä»–æåˆ°äº†å¦ä¸€å€‹æ¯”å–»ï¼Œä¸€éš»ç”Ÿæ´»åœ¨æ·±æµ·ä¸‹çš„ç›²é¾œå’Œä¸€å€‹åœ¨æµ·ä¸­æ¼‚æµ®çš„å¸¶å­”çš„è»›ã€‚é€™éš»ç›²é¾œæ¯ç™¾å¹´æ‰æµ®å‡ºæ°´é¢ä¸€æ¬¡ã€‚

å®ƒåœ¨éå¸¸å»£é—Šçš„æµ·æ´‹ä¸­ç›²ç›®åœ°ç§»å‹•ã€‚å¸¶å­”çš„è»›ä¹Ÿåœ¨æµ·æ´‹ä¸­éš¨æ©Ÿç§»å‹•ã€‚ç¶“éå¾ˆé•·ä¸€æ®µæ™‚é–“ï¼Œç›²é¾œçš„é ­æ„å¤–åœ°é€²å…¥äº†å®ƒçš„å­”ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œä¸€å€‹äººä¸€æ—¦å¢®å…¥æƒ¡é“ï¼Œå¾é‚£è£¡å‡ºä¾†æ¯”ç›²é¾œçš„é ­é€²å…¥å­”ä¸­æ›´å›°é›£ã€‚

è¥¿äºå¤šé€™æ¬¡é–‹ç¤ºæ˜¯åŸºæ–¼ã€Šä¸­éƒ¨å°¼è¿¦è€¶ã€‹ï¼ˆMajjhima NikÄyaï¼‰çš„ã€Šè©å½Œè¿¦ç¶“ã€‹ï¼ˆMN.126 BhÅ«mijasuttaá¹ƒï¼‰ï¼Œè©å½Œè¿¦å°Šè€…å’Œé—è€¶æ–¯é‚£ç‹å­ï¼ˆå”ä¾„ï¼‰ä¹‹é–“çš„è¨è«–ã€‚é—è€¶æ–¯é‚£å‘è©å½Œè¿¦å°Šè€…æå‡ºäº†å››å€‹å•é¡Œã€‚å°‡é€™å››å€‹å•é¡Œåˆä½µåœ¨ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œå°±è®Šæˆäº†å…©å€‹å•é¡Œã€‚

å•é¡Œä¸€ï¼šä¸€äº›ç‘œä¼½å£«ç¥ˆç¦±ä¸¦ä¿®è¡Œï¼Œä½†ç„¡æ³•è­‰å¾—æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚ å•é¡ŒäºŒï¼šä¸€äº›ç‘œä¼½å£«ä¸ç¥ˆç¦±ï¼Œåªä¿®è¡Œï¼Œä½†ç„¡æ³•è­‰å¾—æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚

ä½›é™€å°é€™äº›å•é¡Œçš„çœ‹æ³•æ˜¯ä»€éº¼ï¼Ÿè©å½Œè¿¦å°Šè€…å›ç­”èªªï¼Œä»–å¾æœªè½éä½›é™€æåˆ°é€™äº›å•é¡Œï¼Œä½†ä»–å¯ä»¥ç™¼è¡¨è‡ªå·±çš„çœ‹æ³•ã€‚ä»–èªªï¼Œé€™å…©å€‹å•é¡Œéƒ½æ˜¯åŸºæ–¼ä¸å¦‚ç†ä½œæ„ï¼ˆayonisoï¼‰ï¼Œå› æ­¤ç„¡æ³•è­‰å¾—æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚é—è€¶æ–¯é‚£è«‹ä»–å‘ä½›é™€è©¢å•ç­”æ¡ˆã€‚

è©å½Œè¿¦å°Šè€…å»è¦‹ä½›é™€ï¼Œä¸¦æå‡ºäº†é€™äº›å•é¡Œã€‚ä½›é™€ç”¨ä¸€å€‹æ¯”å–»ï¼Œå°‡æ²™å­æ”¾å…¥ç ”ç£¨å·¥å…·ä¸­ï¼Œç¥ˆç¦±å¾—åˆ°æ²¹ï¼Œä½†æ°¸é ä¸æœƒå¾—åˆ°æ²¹ï¼Œå› ç‚ºæ–¹æ³•ä¸æ­£ç¢ºã€‚è‹¥æ”¾å…¥èŠéº»ï¼Œå³ä½¿æ²’æœ‰ç¥ˆç¦±ï¼Œä¹Ÿæœƒå¾—åˆ°æ²¹ï¼Œå› ç‚ºæ–¹æ³•æ­£ç¢ºã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œåœ¨æ¯—å©†èˆé‚£ä¿®è¡Œä¸­ï¼Œå¦‚ç†ä½œæ„ï¼ˆyonisoï¼‰éå¸¸é‡è¦ï¼Œéœ€è¦è€å¸«çš„å¹«åŠ©ã€‚

è¥¿äºå¤šçµ¦äº†ä¸€å€‹ç°¡å–®çš„æ¯—å©†èˆé‚£æŒ‡å°ã€‚é¦–å…ˆï¼Œé€éçŸ¥é“å‘¼å¸å¾é¼»å­”çš„é€²å‡ºï¼Œä½¿å¿ƒå¹³éœä¸‹ä¾†ã€‚éä¸€æ®µæ™‚é–“å¾Œï¼Œå¿ƒæœƒå¹³éœä¸‹ä¾†ã€‚èº«é«”æœƒé€éæ„Ÿå—é¡¯ç¤ºå…¶æœ¬è³ªã€‚ä»–èˆ‰äº†ä¸€å€‹ä¾‹å­ï¼šä¸€éš»å°èœ¥èœ´åœ¨å¯‚éœçš„åˆå¤œå¾é«˜é«˜çš„å¤©èŠ±æ¿æ‰åˆ°åœ°æ¿ä¸Šã€‚å®ƒæœƒç™¼å‡ºæ¯å€‹äººéƒ½èƒ½è½åˆ°çš„å·¨éŸ¿ã€‚

ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œåœ¨ç™½å¤©å‘¨åœæœ‰å™ªéŸ³çš„æƒ…æ³ä¸‹ï¼Œæ²’æœ‰äººæœƒæ³¨æ„åˆ°å®ƒã€‚åŒæ¨£åœ°ï¼Œæœ‰å®šï¼ˆsamÄdhiï¼‰çš„ç‘œä¼½å£«æœƒçŸ¥é“èº«é«”é¡¯ç¤ºå…¶æœ¬è³ªã€‚å®ƒé¡¯ç¤ºå…¶è®ŠåŒ–çš„æœ¬è³ªã€‚åœ¨å®šä¹‹å‰ï¼Œå®ƒä¹Ÿæœ‰é€™ç¨®æœ¬è³ªã€‚ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œåœ¨å®šä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œå®ƒæœƒçœ‹å¾—æ›´æ¸…æ¥šã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œä½›é™€åœ¨è¨±å¤šç¶“æ–‡ä¸­æ•™å°äº†å®šï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œã€Šå¢æ”¯éƒ¨å°¼è¿¦è€¶ã€‹ï¼‰ã€‚

æœ‰å®šçš„äººæœƒçŸ¥é“äº”è˜Šçš„çœŸå¯¦æœ¬è³ªã€‚è‹¥èº«é«”ç™¼ç™¢ã€ç–¼ç—›ç­‰ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯å—è˜Šï¼ˆvedanÄkkhandhaï¼‰ã€‚å„ç¨®ä¸åŒçš„å¿ƒç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œä¹ŸçŸ¥é“å®ƒã€‚çŸ¥é“å†·ç†±çš„è‰²æ³•ï¼ˆrÅ«paï¼‰ã€‚ç”Ÿèµ·æ­£åœ¨è®ŠåŒ–ï¼Œæ»…å»æ­£åœ¨æ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚åªæœ‰ç„¡å¸¸å­˜åœ¨ã€‚ä¸æ˜¯ç”·äººä¹Ÿä¸æ˜¯å¥³äººï¼Œä¸æ˜¯æˆ‘ï¼Œä¹Ÿä¸æ˜¯ä»–ï¼Œäº”è˜Šæ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚åªçœ‹è¦‹ç”Ÿæ»…ã€‚

è®Šå£ä¹‹ç›¸æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ï¼ˆvipariá¹‡Äma lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ dukkha saccaá¹ï¼‰ã€‚è®ŠåŒ–å’Œæ»…å»æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ã€‚åœ¨çœ‹è¦‹ç„¡å¸¸æ™‚ï¼Œä½ å€‘ä¸éœ€è¦å°‡å®ƒå€‘å€åˆ†ç‚ºèº«å’Œå¿ƒã€‚é€™å°±æ˜¯çœ‹è¦‹æ³•éš¨è§€çš„çœŸç†ï¼Œæ³•éš¨è§€çš„è§€ç…§ã€‚é€™å°±æ˜¯çœ‹è¦‹è‹¦è«¦çš„çœŸç†ï¼Œçœ‹è¦‹å°±æ˜¯é“è«¦ã€‚

ç„¶å¾Œä½ å€‘æœƒå¾—åˆ°æ­£è¦‹ä¹‹çœ¼â€”â€”sammÄ-diá¹­á¹­hiä¹‹çœ¼ã€‚ï¼ˆå¾é€™è£¡åˆ°æ¶…æ§ƒï¼Œè¥¿äºå¤šæåˆ°äº†å¾ˆå¤šäº‹æƒ…ï¼‰ã€‚ä»–ç”¨ä¸€å€‹æ¯”å–»ä¾†èªªæ˜æ¶…æ§ƒå¦‚ä½•é¡¯ç¾ã€‚å°±åƒé›»å½±è¢å¹•ä¸€æ¨£ï¼Œè¨±å¤šç•«é¢ç”Ÿæ»…ï¼Œç”Ÿæ»…ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚é›»å½±çµæŸå¾Œï¼Œç™½è‰²è¢å¹•å°±æœƒé¡¯ç¾ã€‚åŒæ¨£åœ°ï¼Œæ¶…æ§ƒä¹Ÿæœƒé¡¯ç¾ã€‚äº”è˜Šç”Ÿæ»…ï¼Œç”Ÿæ»…ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚åœ¨ç„¡å¸¸çµæŸå¾Œï¼Œä¸€åˆ‡éƒ½æœƒè®Šå¾—æ¸…æ™°ã€‚]

è‹¥ä½ å€‘ä»¥éæ³•çš„æ–¹å¼ç”Ÿæ´»ï¼Œç·£èµ·ï¼ˆD.A.ï¼‰çš„éç¨‹å°±æœƒç¹¼çºŒï¼ˆéæ³•â€”â€”éä½›æ³•çš„æ–¹å¼ã€‚é€™è£¡çš„ä½›æ³•æ˜¯æŒ‡ç¬¦åˆä½›é™€çš„æ•™å°ï¼‰ã€‚è‹¥ä»¥ä½›æ³•ç”Ÿæ´»ï¼Œç·£èµ·çš„éç¨‹å°±æœƒè¢«åˆ‡æ–·ã€‚ç¾åœ¨ï¼Œä»¥ç‹æšçš„éæ³•ï¼Œéš¨ä¹‹è€Œä¾†çš„æ˜¯æ†‚å‚·ï¼ˆsokaï¼‰ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ï¼šçˆ¶æ¯å°å­©å­ä¸æ»¿æ„çš„æ™‚å€™ï¼‰ã€‚

å­©å­ä¸æ˜¯å•é¡Œï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯çˆ¶æ¯è¦å»æƒ¡é“ï¼ˆapÄyaï¼‰ã€‚äººå€‘åœ¨ä»Šç”Ÿä¸è½å¾å’Œä¿®è¡Œä½›æ³•ï¼Œå°±æœƒè®Šæˆéæ³•ã€‚ä»–å€‘æœƒåœ¨è¼ªè¿´ä¸­åœ¨æƒ¡é“ä¸­å¾˜å¾Šã€‚æˆ‘å€‘ä»¥å–„æ³•ä¾†åˆ°é€™å€‹äººé¡ä¸–ç•Œã€‚ä¾†åˆ°é€™è£¡å»åšéæ³•ä¹‹äº‹ï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘æœƒå¤±å»æˆ‘å€‘çš„è³‡æœ¬ï¼ˆå³ï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘çš„å–„æ¥­åœ¨ä»Šç”Ÿè®Šå¾—æ²’æœ‰çµæœï¼‰ã€‚

ä½›é™€ç‚ºé€™ç¨®æå¤±èˆ‰äº†ä¸€äº›æ¯”å–»ï¼ˆæŒ‡ç”²ä¸Šçš„æ³¥åœŸå’Œæµ·æ´‹ä¸­çš„ç›²é¾œçš„æ¯”å–»ï¼‰ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œä½›é™€è­¦å‘Šä½ å€‘äººé¡ç”Ÿå‘½çš„åƒ¹å€¼ã€‚å¾äººé¡ç”Ÿå‘½ï¼Œä½ å€‘å¯ä»¥å»æ¶…æ§ƒï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯å¾æƒ¡é“ï¼ˆapÄyabhÅ«miï¼‰ï¼ˆç¹¼çºŒè¬›è¿°ã€Šè©å½Œè¿¦ç¶“ã€‹ï¼‰ã€‚è­‰å¾—æ¶…æ§ƒçš„å•é¡Œå–æ±ºæ–¼å¦‚ç†/æ­£ç¢ºçš„ä½œæ„ã€‚åŸæœ¬æ²’æœ‰äººæ˜¯æ­£ç¢ºçš„ã€‚å®ƒéœ€è¦è€å¸«çš„å¹«åŠ©ã€‚å°äº”è˜Šæœ‰å¦‚ç†ä½œæ„æ˜¯éå¸¸é‡è¦çš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚

ï¼ˆçµ¦äºˆæ¯—å©†èˆé‚£æŒ‡å°ï¼‰é¦–å…ˆå»ºç«‹å®šç´„15æˆ–20åˆ†é˜ã€‚é€™æ˜¯çµ¦åˆå­¸è€…çš„ã€‚å·²ç¶“è¾¨åˆ¥ç„¡å¸¸çš„äººä¸éœ€è¦å¾é€™è£¡é–‹å§‹ã€‚çŸ¥é“æ¯æ¬¡å‘¼å¸é€²å‡ºçš„è§¸æ„Ÿã€‚éä¸€æ®µæ™‚é–“å¾Œï¼Œå¾—åˆ°å®šï¼Œå¿ƒä¸æœƒè·‘æ‰ï¼Œä¸¦æŒçºŒçŸ¥é“ã€‚

å¿ƒè®Šå¾—å¹³éœï¼Œåƒå¾€å¸¸ä¸€æ¨£å‘¼å¸é€²å‡ºã€‚æœ‰äº†å®šï¼Œèº«é«”æœƒå‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘ï¼›ç™¼ç™¢ã€ç–¼ç—›ã€éº»æœ¨ã€å†·ç†±ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚æœ‰äº†å®šï¼Œç„¡è«–å®ƒå‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘ä»€éº¼ï¼Œä½ å€‘éƒ½çŸ¥é“å—ï¼Ÿï¼ˆä»–èˆ‰äº†ä¸€å€‹èœ¥èœ´åœ¨å¯‚éœçš„åˆå¤œå¾å¤©èŠ±æ¿æ‰åˆ°åœ°æ¿ä¸Šçš„ä¾‹å­ï¼‰ã€‚

äº”è˜Šçš„æœ¬è³ªä»¥ä¸åŒçš„æ–¹å¼é¡¯ç¾ã€‚é€™å°±æ˜¯äº”è˜Šçš„è®ŠåŒ–ã€‚æ²’æœ‰å®šï¼Œäº”è˜Šä¹Ÿåœ¨è®ŠåŒ–ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘å€‘ä¸çŸ¥é“ã€‚æœ‰å®šçš„äººæœƒçŸ¥é“äº”è˜Šçš„çœŸå¯¦é¢ç›®ã€‚å¦‚ä½•æ‰èƒ½çŸ¥é“å®ƒçš„çœŸå¯¦é¢ç›®ï¼Ÿå®ƒå‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘çš„æ˜¯å—è˜Šï¼ˆvedanÄkkhandhaï¼Œæ„Ÿå—è˜Šï¼‰ã€‚ç–¼ç—›ã€æ„Ÿè¦ºè‰¯å¥½å’Œä»‹æ–¼å…©è€…ä¹‹é–“ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å—è˜Šã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œä½ å€‘çŸ¥é“äº”è˜Šä¸­ç”Ÿèµ·å„ç¨®ä¸åŒçš„æ„Ÿå—ã€‚å„ç¨®ä¸åŒçš„å¿ƒç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚è‰²æ³•ï¼ˆrÅ«paï¼‰è®Šå¾—å†·ç†±ï¼Œå¹³éœå’Œç§»å‹•ï¼Œäº”è˜Šæœƒä»¥è¨±å¤šä¸åŒçš„æ–¹å¼å‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘ã€‚ä½›é™€æ•™å°èªªï¼Œäº”è˜Šæ­£åœ¨è®ŠåŒ–ï¼ˆvipariá¹‡Ämaï¼‰ã€‚ç¾åœ¨ï¼Œæ–°çš„æ³•æ­£åœ¨é€éç ´å£èˆŠçš„æ³•è€Œç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚æœ‰äº†å®šï¼Œè§€å¯Ÿç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œå®ƒå°±æœƒæ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚

è®ŠåŒ–æ˜¯ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œæ»…å»æ˜¯æ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œå§‹çµ‚å›åˆ°ç”Ÿæ»…ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œåœ¨äº”è˜Šä¸­ï¼Œåªæœ‰ç”Ÿæ»…æˆ–è®ŠåŒ–å’Œæ»…å»å­˜åœ¨ã€‚å®ƒæ—¢ä¸æ˜¯ç”·äººä¹Ÿä¸æ˜¯å¥³äººã€‚ç„¶å¾Œä¸éœ€è¦æ¶ˆé™¤é‚ªè¦‹ã€‚é‚£æ™‚ä½ å€‘çœ‹ä¸åˆ°ä»»ä½•é¢å­”ã€‚é€éè§€å¯Ÿè®ŠåŒ–ï¼Œç”·äººå’Œå¥³äººå°±æœƒæ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚ç”·äººå’Œå¥³äººåªæ˜¯å£é ­ä¸Šçš„è¨€èªã€‚

é—œé–‰äº”æ ¹é–€ï¼Œæ‰“é–‹ä½ å€‘çš„æ…§çœ¼ï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡a eyeï¼‰ä¾†è§€å¯Ÿã€‚è®Šå£ä¹‹ç›¸æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ï¼ˆvipariá¹‡Äma lakkhaá¹‡aá¹ dukkha saccaá¹ï¼‰ã€‚å®ƒæ­£åœ¨è®ŠåŒ–ï¼Œä¹Ÿåœ¨ç ´å£è‡ªå·±çš„æœ¬è³ªã€‚æ»…å»ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å¦‚æ­¤ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰çš„è®ŠåŒ–å’Œæ»…å»éƒ½æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ã€‚é‚£æ™‚ä¸éœ€è¦å°‡å®ƒå€‘å€åˆ†ç‚ºèº«å’Œå¿ƒã€‚å®ƒè®Šæˆäº†çœ‹è¦‹çœŸç†ï¼Œæ³•éš¨è§€å¿µä½ã€‚è®ŠåŒ–å’Œæ»…å»æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ï¼Œçœ‹è¦‹æˆ–çŸ¥é“æ˜¯é“è«¦ã€‚

é‚£æ™‚å°±è®Šæˆäº†æ­£æ€ç¶­ã€‚æ­£æ€ç¶­æ˜¯èˆ‡æ™ºæ…§ï¼ˆpaÃ±Ã±Äï¼‰ä¸€èµ·ï¼Œæ­£è¦‹ä¹‹çœ¼â€”â€”sammÄ-diá¹­á¹­hiã€‚å®ƒä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ™ºæ…§ä¹‹çœ¼â€”â€”vijjÄä¹‹çœ¼ã€‚å¯¦éš›ä¸Šï¼Œåªæœ‰ä¸€å€‹æ…§çœ¼ï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡a eyeï¼‰ã€‚ç¾åœ¨ï¼Œä½ å€‘å¾—åˆ°äº†çœ‹è¦‹è‹¦çš„çœ¼ç›ã€‚ä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œä½ å€‘å¿…é ˆå¾—åˆ°çœ‹è¦‹æ¶…æ§ƒçš„çœ¼ç›ã€‚

è®ŠåŒ–å’Œæ»…å»æ˜¯ç„¡å¸¸ã€ä¹Ÿæ˜¯è‹¦å’Œç„¡æˆ‘ã€‚åªæœ‰çœ‹è¦‹çœŸç†æ‰èƒ½çœ‹è¦‹æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚è§€ç…§ç„¡å¸¸å°±æ˜¯è§€ç…§çœŸç†ã€‚é€™ä¸æ˜¯æ„Ÿå®˜äº«æ¨‚å’Œè‡ªæˆ‘æŠ˜ç£¨çš„æ–¹å¼ã€‚é€™æ˜¯ä¸­é“ã€‚å®ƒåˆ°é”è²ªæ„›å’Œç‹æšçš„ä¸­é–“ã€‚éš¨è‘—æ™‚é–“çš„æ¨ç§»ï¼Œè§€æ™ºï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡aï¼‰æœƒè®Šå¾—æˆç†Ÿä¸¦ç”¢ç”Ÿå­é›¢ã€‚

ç‚ºä»€éº¼æœƒé€™æ¨£å‘¢ï¼Ÿå› ç‚ºä½ å€‘çœ‹è¦‹çš„æ˜¯ç”Ÿæ»…ã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘ç¶“å¸¸çœ‹è¦‹ï¼Œå®ƒæœƒç™¼å±•æˆå­é›¢æ™ºï¼ˆNibbidÄ Ã‘Äá¹‡aï¼‰ã€‚ä¹‹å‰ä½ å€‘èªç‚ºé€™æ˜¯å¾—åˆ°æ­£ç¢ºçš„æ±è¥¿ã€‚ä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œä¸åƒ…æœƒå°å®ƒç”¢ç”Ÿå­é›¢ï¼Œé‚„æœƒç™¼å±•æˆä¸æƒ³è¦å’Œä¸å¾—åˆ°çš„ç‹€æ…‹ã€‚

ç•¶é€™ç¨®æƒ…æ³ç™¼ç”Ÿæ™‚ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰çš„ç”Ÿæ»…éƒ½æœƒåŒæ™‚æ¶ˆå¤±ï¼ˆå³ï¼Œäº”è˜Šæ¶ˆå¤±ï¼‰ã€‚ä¸¦ä¸”å®ƒæœƒè½‰å‘æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚ä¸ç”Ÿæ»…çš„ç©©å®šæ¶…æ§ƒæœƒé¡¯ç¾ã€‚ï¼ˆè¥¿äºå¤šç”¨é›»å½±æ”¾æ˜ çš„æ¯”å–»ä¾†èªªæ˜æ¯—å©†èˆé‚£çš„éç¨‹ï¼‰ã€‚ä¹‹å‰ï¼Œå®ƒå› ç„¡å¸¸è€Œæ··äº‚ï¼Œæ¶…æ§ƒé¡¯ç¾å¾Œï¼Œä¸€åˆ‡éƒ½æœƒè®Šå¾—æ¸…æ™°ã€‚




Truth Is in the Khandha



15th June 1962


Cutting off saá¹sÄra is turning ignorance into knowledge. Observe with samÄdhi and saá¹sÄra will be cut off. A person no practice is in the whole day doing ignorance and action (avijjÄ and saá¹…khÄra). Mind process going on and on is saá¹sÄra.


The Buddha asked for practice was to know the truth. Where is the truth? It exists in the khandha. This khandha is the truth of dukkha. If you are looking at it and seeing as a lump of matter, and donâ€™t know it yet. For fixing a Ã±Äá¹‡a eye, have to develop samÄdhi and look at it.


Then you see its changing nature from the old one to the new one as vibrations. This is the truth of dukkha. You have to look at it with the knowledge eye. At normal, we are moving around, we canâ€™t see it even the khandha shows its nature. After establish samÄdhi and see its change. Its true nature appears to us. There is vibrations, here is itching and there is aching. Different kinds of mind and feeling arise, cold, heat, tiredness, etc.


Its original nature appears to us. After disbanding the beginning of the sitting nature, it tells you its arising new nature. The old nature disappears and new nature arises. The khandha tells you as I am the truth of dukkha. Except the arising and vanishing the khandha has nothing to tell you.


Khandha is the teller and Ã±Äá¹‡a is the observer. (Sayadaw was using the words of the Buddha in the first discourse to express the experience) Cakkhuá¹ udapÄdiâ€”vision arises; Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ udapÄdiâ€”the knowledge of seeing dukkha sacca arises; aloko udapÄdiâ€”light arises. Before because of the darkness of ignorance canâ€™t see it, element of light arises for seeing the khandha; vijjÄ udapÄdiâ€”knowing arises and not knowing disappears.


Cakkhuá¹ udapÄdi is not the ordinary eye vision but Ã±Äá¹‡a eye. Therefore, the Buddha continued to mention Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ udapÄdi. It becomes knowledge and D. A. process canâ€™t continue. So, without sati and observation whatever we think, speak and act become ignorance, volitional formation and consciousness (avijjÄ â†’ saá¹…khÄra â†’ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹).


There are arising and ceasing with many ignorances, volitional formations and consciousnesses etc., the whole day. This is saá¹sÄra. So saá¹sÄra is the aggregate of dukkha. If you donâ€™t cut it off dukkha is your own property. Khandha process and saá¹sÄric process are the same. Saá¹sÄra is; what is happening now. Nothing will become in the future if we can cut it here. With sati and paÃ±Ã±Ä no ignorance and only knowledge arises.


Therefore, saá¹sÄra is wrong seeing, wrong hearing â€¦â€¦â€¦ and wrong thinking and starting from the six sensesâ€doors. If not encounter a good teacher vijjÄ udapÄdi not arises. After establish samÄdhi and follow what the khandha is telling you and become vijjÄ udapÄdi. During establishing samÄdhi is samatha. Become vijjÄ udapÄdi is vipassanÄ.


[Sayadaw reminded yogis how much important to become vijjÄ udapÄdi. He quoted the words of the Buddha; if someone comes to you and says, â€˜â€˜Iâ€™ll teach you to end identity viewâ€”SakkÄya diá¹­á¹­hi. But you must take the pain of the body which Iâ€™ll use a spear on your body three times a day, each time 300 spears of inflictionsâ€™â€™ The Buddha said â€˜â€˜You must take these pains for the sake of destroying diá¹­á¹­hi because dukkha will never end if you donâ€™t realize the truth.â€™â€™ (from Saccasaá¹ƒyutta)]


If you look at things with the ignorant eyeâ€”avijjÄ eye and think what will happen to me and diá¹­á¹­hi come in. SotÄpanna is easy. Listening sacca dhamma and with wise attention (yoniso) will become sotÄpanna.


For example, I tell you feeling is dukkha sacca. And you observe the khandha and seeing impermanence. Continue with the practice and sure to become a sotÄpanna. Thoroughly penetrating dukkha is knowledge of the fuctionâ€”kicca Ã±Äá¹‡a. Dukkha is in the khandha and Ã±Äá¹‡a also in the khandha. Itâ€™s very near but we are far away from it.


So, saá¹sÄra is becoming very long for us. Not knowing the arising does also not knowing the ceasing. And it becomes ignorance. Even itâ€™s closer if the mind observes the mind (i.e., cittÄnupassanÄ). Mind is at the heart base (hadayaâ€vatthu) and Ã±Äá¹‡a also at the same place.


Observing the khandha with good samÄdhi is your duty. The teacherâ€™s duty is teaching the sacca dhamma. The disciple will enter the stream if he is seeing in accordance with the truth.

æ‰€ä»¥ï¼š

ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½ï½


çœŸç†å°±åœ¨äº”è˜Šä¸­

ä¸€ä¹å…­äºŒå¹´å…­æœˆåäº”æ—¥

åˆ‡æ–·è¼ªè¿´ï¼ˆsaá¹sÄraï¼‰å°±æ˜¯å°‡ç„¡æ˜è½‰åŒ–ç‚ºæ™ºæ…§ã€‚é€éå®šï¼ˆsamÄdhiï¼‰è§€å¯Ÿï¼Œè¼ªè¿´å°±æœƒè¢«åˆ‡æ–·ã€‚ä¸ä¿®è¡Œçš„äººæ•´å¤©éƒ½åœ¨åšç„¡æ˜å’Œè¡Œç‚ºï¼ˆavijjÄå’Œsaá¹…khÄraï¼‰ã€‚å¿ƒè­˜éç¨‹ä¸æ–·é€²è¡Œå°±æ˜¯è¼ªè¿´ã€‚

ä½›é™€è¦æ±‚ä¿®è¡Œæ˜¯ç‚ºäº†çŸ¥é“çœŸç†ã€‚çœŸç†åœ¨å“ªè£¡ï¼Ÿå®ƒå­˜åœ¨æ–¼äº”è˜Šä¸­ã€‚é€™å€‹äº”è˜Šå°±æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦çš„çœŸç†ã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘çœ‹è‘—å®ƒï¼ŒæŠŠå®ƒçœ‹ä½œä¸€åœ˜ç‰©è³ªï¼Œå°±é‚„ä¸çŸ¥é“å®ƒã€‚ç‚ºäº†å›ºå®šæ…§çœ¼ï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡a eyeï¼‰ï¼Œå¿…é ˆç™¼å±•å®šä¸¦çœ‹è‘—å®ƒã€‚

ç„¶å¾Œä½ å€‘æœƒçœ‹åˆ°å®ƒå¾èˆŠçš„æœ¬è³ªåˆ°æ–°çš„æœ¬è³ªçš„è®ŠåŒ–ï¼Œå°±åƒæŒ¯å‹•ä¸€æ¨£ã€‚é€™å°±æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦çš„çœŸç†ã€‚ä½ å€‘å¿…é ˆç”¨æ™ºæ…§ä¹‹çœ¼çœ‹è‘—å®ƒã€‚åœ¨æ­£å¸¸æƒ…æ³ä¸‹ï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘å››è™•èµ°å‹•ï¼Œå³ä½¿äº”è˜Šé¡¯ç¤ºå…¶æœ¬è³ªï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘ä¹Ÿçœ‹ä¸åˆ°å®ƒã€‚å»ºç«‹å®šä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œå°±æœƒçœ‹åˆ°å®ƒçš„è®ŠåŒ–ã€‚å®ƒçš„çœŸå¯¦æœ¬è³ªæœƒå‘æˆ‘å€‘é¡¯ç¾ã€‚é€™è£¡æœ‰æŒ¯å‹•ï¼Œé€™è£¡ç™¼ç™¢ï¼Œé‚£è£¡ç–¼ç—›ã€‚å„ç¨®ä¸åŒçš„å¿ƒå’Œæ„Ÿå—ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œå†·ã€ç†±ã€ç–²å€¦ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚

å®ƒçš„åŸå§‹æœ¬è³ªæœƒå‘æˆ‘å€‘é¡¯ç¾ã€‚åœ¨ç ´å£åå§¿çš„åˆå§‹æœ¬è³ªä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œå®ƒæœƒå‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘å®ƒç”Ÿèµ·çš„æ–°æœ¬è³ªã€‚èˆŠçš„æœ¬è³ªæ¶ˆå¤±ï¼Œæ–°çš„æœ¬è³ªç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚äº”è˜Šå‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘ï¼Œæˆ‘æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦çš„çœŸç†ã€‚é™¤äº†ç”Ÿæ»…ä¹‹å¤–ï¼Œäº”è˜Šæ²’æœ‰ä»€éº¼å¯ä»¥å‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘çš„ã€‚

äº”è˜Šæ˜¯è¬›è¿°è€…ï¼Œè§€æ™ºï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡aï¼‰æ˜¯è§€å¯Ÿè€…ã€‚ï¼ˆè¥¿äºå¤šç”¨ä½›é™€åœ¨åˆè½‰æ³•è¼ªä¸­çš„è©±ä¾†è¡¨é”é€™ç¨®é«”é©—ï¼‰çœ¼ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆcakkhuá¹ udapÄdiï¼‰â€”â€”è¦–è¦ºç”Ÿèµ·ï¼›æ™ºç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ udapÄdiï¼‰â€”â€”çœ‹è¦‹è‹¦è«¦çš„çŸ¥è­˜ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼›å…‰ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆaloko udapÄdiï¼‰â€”â€”å…‰å…ƒç´ ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œå› ç‚ºä¹‹å‰çš„ç„¡æ˜é»‘æš—çœ‹ä¸åˆ°å®ƒï¼Œå…‰å…ƒç´ ç”Ÿèµ·æ˜¯ç‚ºäº†çœ‹è¦‹äº”è˜Šï¼›æ˜ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆvijjÄ udapÄdiï¼‰â€”â€”çŸ¥é“ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œä¸çŸ¥é“æ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚

çœ¼ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆcakkhuá¹ udapÄdiï¼‰ä¸æ˜¯æ™®é€šçš„è¦–è¦ºï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯æ…§çœ¼ï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡a eyeï¼‰ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œä½›é™€ç¹¼çºŒæåˆ°æ™ºç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ udapÄdiï¼‰ã€‚å®ƒè®Šæˆäº†çŸ¥è­˜ï¼Œç·£èµ·ï¼ˆD.A.ï¼‰çš„éç¨‹ç„¡æ³•ç¹¼çºŒã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ²’æœ‰æ­£å¿µï¼ˆsatiï¼‰å’Œè§€å¯Ÿï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘æ‰€æœ‰çš„æ€æƒ³ã€è¨€èªå’Œè¡Œç‚ºéƒ½æœƒè®Šæˆç„¡æ˜ã€è¡Œå’Œè­˜ï¼ˆavijjÄ â†’ saá¹…khÄra â†’ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ï¼‰ã€‚

æ•´å¤©éƒ½æœ‰è¨±å¤šç„¡æ˜ã€è¡Œå’Œè­˜ç­‰ç­‰çš„ç”Ÿæ»…ã€‚é€™å°±æ˜¯è¼ªè¿´ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œè¼ªè¿´æ˜¯è‹¦çš„é›†åˆã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘ä¸åˆ‡æ–·å®ƒï¼Œè‹¦å°±æ˜¯ä½ å€‘è‡ªå·±çš„è²¡ç”¢ã€‚äº”è˜Šçš„éç¨‹å’Œè¼ªè¿´çš„éç¨‹æ˜¯ç›¸åŒçš„ã€‚è¼ªè¿´å°±æ˜¯ç¾åœ¨ç™¼ç”Ÿçš„äº‹æƒ…ã€‚è‹¥æˆ‘å€‘èƒ½åœ¨é€™è£¡åˆ‡æ–·å®ƒï¼Œæœªä¾†å°±ä¸æœƒç™¼ç”Ÿä»»ä½•äº‹æƒ…ã€‚æœ‰äº†æ­£å¿µå’Œæ™ºæ…§ï¼Œæ²’æœ‰ç„¡æ˜ï¼Œåªæœ‰çŸ¥è­˜ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œè¼ªè¿´æ˜¯éŒ¯èª¤çš„çœ‹è¦‹ã€éŒ¯èª¤çš„è½è¦‹â€¦â€¦å’ŒéŒ¯èª¤çš„æ€è€ƒï¼Œå¾å…­æ ¹é–€é–‹å§‹ã€‚è‹¥æ²’æœ‰é‡åˆ°å–„çŸ¥è­˜ï¼Œæ˜ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆvijjÄ udapÄdiï¼‰å°±ä¸æœƒç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚å»ºç«‹å®šä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œè·Ÿéš¨äº”è˜Šå‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘çš„ï¼Œå°±æœƒè®Šæˆæ˜ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆvijjÄ udapÄdiï¼‰ã€‚å»ºç«‹å®šæ™‚æ˜¯æ­¢ï¼ˆsamathaï¼‰ã€‚è®Šæˆæ˜ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆvijjÄ udapÄdiï¼‰æ˜¯è§€ï¼ˆvipassanÄï¼‰ã€‚

[è¥¿äºå¤šæé†’ç‘œä¼½å£«æ˜ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆvijjÄ udapÄdiï¼‰æœ‰å¤šé‡è¦ã€‚ä»–å¼•ç”¨äº†ä½›é™€çš„è©±ï¼›è‹¥æœ‰äººä¾†æ‰¾ä½ å€‘èªªï¼Œã€Œæˆ‘æœƒæ•™ä½ å€‘çµæŸæœ‰èº«è¦‹ï¼ˆSakkÄya diá¹­á¹­hiï¼‰ã€‚ä½†ä½ å€‘å¿…é ˆæ‰¿å—æˆ‘ç”¨çŸ›æ¯å¤©ä¸‰æ¬¡åˆºä½ å€‘èº«é«”çš„ç—›è‹¦ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡ä¸‰ç™¾çŸ›çš„æŠ˜ç£¨ã€‚ã€ä½›é™€èªªï¼Œã€Œä½ å€‘å¿…é ˆç‚ºäº†æ‘§æ¯€é‚ªè¦‹è€Œæ‰¿å—é€™äº›ç—›è‹¦ï¼Œå› ç‚ºè‹¥ä½ å€‘ä¸è­‰å¾—çœŸç†ï¼Œè‹¦æ°¸é ä¸æœƒçµæŸã€‚ã€ï¼ˆä¾†è‡ªã€Šç›¸æ‡‰éƒ¨ã€‹ï¼‰]

è‹¥ä½ å€‘ç”¨ç„¡æ˜ä¹‹çœ¼ï¼ˆavijjÄ eyeï¼‰çœ‹äº‹ç‰©ï¼Œä¸¦æƒ³è‘—æˆ‘æœƒç™¼ç”Ÿä»€éº¼äº‹ï¼Œé‚ªè¦‹å°±æœƒé€²å…¥ã€‚è­‰å¾—é æµæœï¼ˆsotÄpannaï¼‰å¾ˆå®¹æ˜“ã€‚è½èè«¦æ³•ï¼ˆsacca dhammaï¼‰ä¸¦å¦‚ç†ä½œæ„ï¼ˆyonisoï¼‰ï¼Œå°±æœƒæˆç‚ºé æµæœã€‚

ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œæˆ‘å‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘æ„Ÿå—æ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ã€‚ä½ å€‘è§€å¯Ÿäº”è˜Šä¸¦çœ‹è¦‹ç„¡å¸¸ã€‚ç¹¼çºŒä¿®è¡Œï¼Œè‚¯å®šæœƒæˆç‚ºé æµæœã€‚å¾¹åº•ç©¿é€è‹¦å°±æ˜¯åŠŸèƒ½çš„çŸ¥è­˜ï¼ˆkicca Ã±Äá¹‡aï¼‰ã€‚è‹¦åœ¨äº”è˜Šä¸­ï¼Œè§€æ™ºï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡aï¼‰ä¹Ÿåœ¨äº”è˜Šä¸­ã€‚å®ƒéå¸¸è¿‘ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘å€‘é›¢å®ƒå¾ˆé ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œè¼ªè¿´å°æˆ‘å€‘ä¾†èªªè®Šå¾—éå¸¸æ¼«é•·ã€‚ä¸çŸ¥é“ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œä¹Ÿä¸çŸ¥é“æ»…å»ã€‚å®ƒå°±è®Šæˆäº†ç„¡æ˜ã€‚å³ä½¿å¿ƒè§€ç…§å¿ƒï¼ˆå³å¿ƒçš„è§€ç…§ï¼ŒcittÄnupassanÄï¼‰æ›´æ¥è¿‘ã€‚å¿ƒåœ¨è‚‰åœ˜å¿ƒï¼ˆhadaya-vatthuï¼‰ï¼Œè§€æ™ºï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡aï¼‰ä¹Ÿåœ¨åŒä¸€å€‹åœ°æ–¹ã€‚

ç”¨å¥½çš„å®šè§€å¯Ÿäº”è˜Šæ˜¯ä½ å€‘çš„è²¬ä»»ã€‚è€å¸«çš„è²¬ä»»æ˜¯æ•™å°è«¦æ³•ã€‚è‹¥å¼Ÿå­æŒ‰ç…§çœŸç†çœ‹è¦‹ï¼Œå°±æœƒé€²å…¥é æµæœã€‚


NibbÄna Is the Foremost Happiness



15th June 1962


Sayadaw based on the verses of the Buddha Kassapa which was mentioned in the MÄgandiya Sutta of the Majjhima NikÄya, taught by the Buddha Gautama to MÄgandiya brahman (MN.75 MÄgaá¹‡á¸iyasuttaá¹ƒ). â€˜â€˜Freedom from disease: The foremost good fortune. NibbÄna: the foremost happiness. â€™â€™


But after hearing these verses, MÄgandiya responded that my body was healthy, so it was NibbÄna because these verses have been existed in their Brahmin Teachings and handed down by their ancestors from the time of the Buddha Kassapa. They were using it and interpreting it wrongly (Itâ€™s very similar like later Buddhists using and interpreting the Buddha teaching in different ways).


Sayadaw said how it could be that his body was healthy. With samÄdhi and observe this body, we can see their unhealthy nature directly, such as pains, itches, aches and changing, etc. In our daily life, we have to adjust and look after the body all the times.


(Such as: feeding it, clothing it, going to the toilet for many times a day. And then has to change postures all the times; even in sleep turning it around to release its discomfort. There are four functions of dukkha sacca; PÄ«á¸·anaá¹­á¹­haâ€”oppressive, Saá¹…khatathaâ€”conditioning, SantÄpathaâ€”burning and Vipariá¹‡Ämathaâ€”changing. Among them Saá¹…khatatha is quite extensive. Contemplation of this dukkha in daily practice is very important for practice).


Where is the healthy nature of this body? Surely, the body is never healthy. The Buddha referred to this body as rogato (disease), ganthato (thorn), sÄlÄto (dart), etc. With the ariyan eye (noble eye), sacca eye and will see it. Therefore, without this khandha is really healthy, the real fortune and the real happiness.


The Buddha himself taught that the five khandhas were dukkha sacca. How can it be without disease and real happiness? The views are quite different between ariyan and worldly. Looking with the taá¹‡hÄ and diá¹­á¹­hi eye and it seem healthy. You will see it as unhealthy if you fix with the ariyan eye and Ã±Äá¹‡a eye and looking at it. Youâ€™ll find the disease and knowing it as dukkha sacca.


The way of practice is; first, to approach a teacher; second, listening to the sacca dhamma; third, if you see the truth and will see the happy NibbÄna without the disease. With the practice, youâ€™ll also know that the khandha has disease. With good samÄdhi and paÃ±Ã±Ä will see its unhealthy nature and want to be free from disease. Without seeing dukkha sacca and you canâ€™t appreciate nirodha sacca.


Only see the disease and you want to be cured. At first, have to discern the disease, later seeing its disenchantment and at last seeing its ending. And youâ€™ll see NibbÄna without disease. You always have the disease if you have the khandha. Without it, it is NibbÄna Happiness.

â— é‚£éº¼ï¼Œã€Œé€™å€‹èº«é«”å“ªè£¡å¥åº·å‘¢ï¼Ÿã€

å”¯æœ‰è–è€…ä¹‹çœ¼ï¼ˆariyan eyeï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ–è¦‹è«¦ä¹‹çœ¼ï¼ˆsacca eyeï¼‰ï¼Œ
æ–¹èƒ½çœ‹è¦‹æ­¤çœŸç›¸ã€‚

ä¸€ä¹å…­äºŒå¹´å…­æœˆåäº”æ—¥

è¥¿äºå¤šæ ¹æ“šè¿¦è‘‰ä½›çš„åˆé Œé€²è¡Œäº†è¬›è§£ï¼Œè©²åˆé Œåœ¨ã€Šä¸­éƒ¨å°¼è¿¦è€¶ã€‹çš„ã€Šæ‘©çŠæç¶“ã€‹ï¼ˆMN.75 MÄgaá¹‡á¸iyasuttaá¹ƒï¼‰ä¸­è¢«æåŠï¼Œç”±å–¬é”æ‘©ä½›é™€å‘æ‘©çŠæå©†ç¾…é–€è¬›è§£ã€‚ ã€Œç„¡ç—…ï¼šè‡³ä¸Šçš„å‰ç¥¥ã€‚æ¶…æ§ƒï¼šè‡³ä¸Šçš„å¹¸ç¦ã€‚ã€

ä½†æ˜¯ï¼Œåœ¨è½å®Œé€™äº›åˆé Œå¾Œï¼Œæ‘©çŠæå›æ‡‰èªªï¼Œä»–çš„èº«é«”å¾ˆå¥åº·ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥é€™å°±æ˜¯æ¶…æ§ƒï¼Œå› ç‚ºé€™äº›åˆé Œåœ¨ä»–å€‘çš„å©†ç¾…é–€æ•™ç¾©ä¸­ä¸€ç›´å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œä¸¦å¾è¿¦è‘‰ä½›æ™‚ä»£èµ·ç”±ä»–å€‘çš„ç¥–å…ˆå‚³ä¸‹ä¾†ã€‚ä»–å€‘éŒ¯èª¤åœ°ä½¿ç”¨å’Œè§£é‡‹å®ƒï¼ˆé€™éå¸¸é¡ä¼¼æ–¼å¾Œä¾†çš„ä½›æ•™å¾’ä»¥ä¸åŒçš„æ–¹å¼ä½¿ç”¨å’Œè§£é‡‹ä½›é™€çš„æ•™ç¾©ï¼‰ã€‚

è¥¿äºå¤šèªªï¼Œä»–çš„èº«é«”æ€éº¼å¯èƒ½å¥åº·ã€‚é€éå®šï¼ˆsamÄdhiï¼‰è§€å¯Ÿé€™å€‹èº«é«”ï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘å¯ä»¥ç›´è§€åœ°çœ‹åˆ°å®ƒå€‘ä¸å¥åº·çš„æœ¬è³ªï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ç–¼ç—›ã€ç˜™ç™¢ã€é…¸ç—›å’Œè®ŠåŒ–ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚åœ¨æˆ‘å€‘çš„æ—¥å¸¸ç”Ÿæ´»ä¸­ï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘å¿…é ˆå§‹çµ‚èª¿æ•´å’Œç…§é¡§èº«é«”ã€‚

ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚ï¼šé¤µé¤Šå®ƒã€ç©¿è¡£ã€æ¯å¤©å¤šæ¬¡ä¸Šå»æ‰€ã€‚ç„¶å¾Œå¿…é ˆå§‹çµ‚æ”¹è®Šå§¿å‹¢ï¼›å³ä½¿åœ¨ç¡çœ ä¸­ä¹Ÿè¦ç¿»èº«ä»¥é‡‹æ”¾å…¶ä¸é©ã€‚è‹¦è«¦æœ‰å››ç¨®åŠŸèƒ½ï¼›é€¼è¿«æ€§ï¼ˆPÄ«á¸·anaá¹­á¹­haï¼‰ã€æœ‰ç‚ºæ€§ï¼ˆSaá¹…khatathaï¼‰ã€ç‡’ç¼æ€§ï¼ˆSantÄpathaï¼‰å’Œè®Šå£æ€§ï¼ˆVipariá¹‡Ämathaï¼‰ã€‚å…¶ä¸­ï¼Œæœ‰ç‚ºæ€§ç›¸ç•¶å»£æ³›ã€‚åœ¨æ—¥å¸¸ä¿®è¡Œä¸­è§€ç…§é€™ç¨®è‹¦éå¸¸é‡è¦ã€‚ï¼‰

é€™å€‹èº«é«”çš„å¥åº·æœ¬è³ªåœ¨å“ªè£¡ï¼Ÿç•¶ç„¶ï¼Œèº«é«”å¾ä¾†éƒ½ä¸æ˜¯å¥åº·çš„ã€‚ä½›é™€å°‡é€™å€‹èº«é«”ç¨±ç‚ºç–¾ç—…ï¼ˆrogatoï¼‰ã€èŠæ£˜ï¼ˆganthatoï¼‰ã€ç®­çŸ¢ï¼ˆsÄlÄtoï¼‰ç­‰ç­‰ã€‚é€éè–çœ¼ï¼ˆariyan eyeï¼Œnoble eyeï¼‰ã€è«¦çœ¼ï¼Œæ‰èƒ½çœ‹è¦‹å®ƒã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œæ²’æœ‰é€™å€‹äº”è˜Šæ‰æ˜¯çœŸæ­£çš„å¥åº·ã€çœŸæ­£çš„å‰ç¥¥å’ŒçœŸæ­£çš„å¹¸ç¦ã€‚

ä½›é™€è¦ªè‡ªæ•™å°èªªï¼Œäº”è˜Šæ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ã€‚æ²’æœ‰ç–¾ç—…å’ŒçœŸæ­£çš„å¹¸ç¦æ€éº¼å¯èƒ½å‘¢ï¼Ÿè–è€…å’Œä¸–ä¿—è€…çš„è§€é»æˆªç„¶ä¸åŒã€‚ç”¨è²ªæ„›å’Œé‚ªè¦‹ä¹‹çœ¼çœ‹ï¼Œå®ƒä¼¼ä¹æ˜¯å¥åº·çš„ã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘ç”¨è–çœ¼å’Œæ…§çœ¼ï¼ˆÃ±Äá¹‡a eyeï¼‰å›ºå®šå®ƒä¸¦çœ‹è‘—å®ƒï¼Œå°±æœƒçœ‹åˆ°å®ƒæ˜¯ä¸å¥åº·çš„ã€‚ä½ å€‘æœƒç™¼ç¾ç–¾ç—…ï¼Œä¸¦çŸ¥é“å®ƒæ˜¯è‹¦è«¦ã€‚

ä¿®è¡Œçš„æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯ï¼šç¬¬ä¸€ï¼Œæ¥è¿‘è€å¸«ï¼›ç¬¬äºŒï¼Œè½èè«¦æ³•ï¼›ç¬¬ä¸‰ï¼Œè‹¥ä½ å€‘çœ‹è¦‹çœŸç†ï¼Œå°±æœƒçœ‹è¦‹æ²’æœ‰ç–¾ç—…çš„å¿«æ¨‚æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚é€éä¿®è¡Œï¼Œä½ å€‘ä¹ŸæœƒçŸ¥é“äº”è˜Šæœ‰ç–¾ç—…ã€‚æœ‰äº†å¥½çš„å®šå’Œæ™ºæ…§ï¼Œå°±æœƒçœ‹è¦‹å…¶ä¸å¥åº·çš„æœ¬è³ªï¼Œä¸¦æƒ³è¦å¾ç–¾ç—…ä¸­è§£è„«ã€‚è‹¥æ²’æœ‰çœ‹è¦‹è‹¦è«¦ï¼Œä½ å€‘å°±ç„¡æ³•æ¬£è³æ»…è«¦ã€‚

åªæœ‰çœ‹è¦‹ç–¾ç—…ï¼Œä½ å€‘æ‰æœƒæƒ³è¦è¢«æ²»æ„ˆã€‚é¦–å…ˆï¼Œå¿…é ˆè¾¨åˆ¥ç–¾ç—…ï¼Œç„¶å¾Œçœ‹è¦‹å…¶å­é›¢ï¼Œæœ€å¾Œçœ‹è¦‹å…¶æ­¢æ¯ã€‚ä½ å€‘æœƒçœ‹è¦‹æ²’æœ‰ç–¾ç—…çš„æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘æœ‰äº”è˜Šï¼Œå°±æœƒä¸€ç›´æœ‰ç–¾ç—…ã€‚æ²’æœ‰å®ƒï¼Œå°±æ˜¯æ¶…æ§ƒçš„å¹¸ç¦ã€‚


To Have Compassion and Wisdom for Oneself



16th June 1962


Only by knowing the objects of contemplation, you will know what to contemplate. If not, you are sitting there by wasting time. What are the objects of contemplation? For example, if the eyes see form and eye consciousness arises. Itâ€™s the beginning of the object of contemplation and also the beginning of D. A. process. After the seeing and the feeling of choosing good or bad arises.


At that moment you are alive with feeling. Seeing is the beginning and choosing good or bad is the second. Phassa paccaya vedanÄâ€”contact conditions feeling. This is called saá¹sÄra. After feeling ceases and craving arises. VedanÄ paccaya taá¹‡hÄâ€”Feeling conditions craving.


So, at that moment you are with taá¹‡hÄ. After that clinging and action arise (upÄdÄnaá¹ and kamma bhava) These are objects of contemplation: â‘  Eye consciouscess â‘¡ Feeling â‘¢ Craving â‘£ Clinging â‘¤ action. After â‘  ceases and â‘¡ arises, â‘¡ ceases and â‘¢ arises, etc.


The five minds are in a process. After, you will get the new khandha in next life. That is kamma paccaya jÄtiâ€”Action conditions birth. The mind process arises one by one. The others five senseâ€doors are also in the same way. In the whole day from the six sensesâ€doors actions are arising. In each day the causes of births are uncountable. (This is the reason why the beginning of a being is indiscernible.)


Therefore, the debts for bodily, verbal and mental kammas are quite a lot. We have to cut off these kammas. From the eyeâ€door, the three D. A. processes of greed, hatred and delusion (lobha, dosa and moha) arise. The other doors also know in this way (6 * 3 = 18).


Every day unwholesome kammas are uncountable. You can only cut them off with the path knowledge. Therefore, the Buddha said that the permanent homes of living beings were the four woeful planes. So the wanderings in saá¹sÄra are quite frightening.


D.A. process is showing the objects for contemplation. You canâ€™t do it blindly. Only by knowing whatâ€™s arising and youâ€™ll see the falling away. Mind arises one by one. Every living being is alive with one mind. Every day a lot of kammas are arising.


Therefore, your wholesome kammas which you have done only sometimes are incomparable with them. Also without the D. A. process and you canâ€™t be alive. Make note of this point. If you donâ€™t get the insight knowledge and all these kammas are not become fruitless. It is not my fault if you donâ€™t know what have to contemplate. You donâ€™t know what happening in you that and canâ€™t do it.


Iâ€™ll show you the contemplation. Contemplate the impermanence of the mind, good or bad feeling. If you can contemplate them, taá¹‡hÄ, upÄdÄna and kamma canâ€™t arise. Every time if it arises with contemplation cut off the round of existence of defilements, action and result (kilesa, kamma and vipÄka vaá¹­á¹­as). So, this is asking you to cut off the three rounds of existence. The Buddha and teachers taught people with wisdom and compassion together. If not with compassion they wouldnâ€™t give their times.


They could teach the truth (sacca) meant including wisdom. Both qualities have to be going together. It's no completion if one of them is lacking. It is useless talking without paÃ±Ã±Ä. From the point of disciples also need compassion and wisdom. Have compassion for oneself to liberate from dukkha, and wisdom to understand what the teacher has said. Have compassion for yourself.


Take notes with wisdom to my talk. If not you can get the merit but not wisdom. It will be like the same as a frog listening to the talk of the Buddha. If you are listening the talk for merit, then like the frog. So, listen with a human mind for the talk. How to listen a talk also important?


When you contemplate on the arising dhamma (here is seeing), it already is passing away and not existing anymore. You are not alive with the seeing consciousness, and instead with the path factors consciousness. VipassanÄ contemplation is abandoning the khandha means this point. Also it is abandoning kilesas not following with taá¹‡hÄ and upÄdÄnaá¹.


Therefore, insight knowledge are abandoning khandha and kilesa. With the abandonment of khandha and wrong view also falls off because there is nothing to be called as a person or a being. It is really crazy if youâ€™re making something out of nothing as me and mine.


(This point is quite funny. If we observe carefully and contemplate human problems and most of the sufferings are coming out from nothing, just stupidity and foolishness).


It will never become useless if you die with the vipassanÄ mind because after you arrive to the blissful plane and you'll enter the stream (There was a talk on this matter by the Buddha in the Aá¹…guttara NikÄya). Therefore, it is not important that you realize the Path Knowledge or not. Just do the practice and it will abandon taá¹‡hÄ and kilesa.


(Sayadaw continued to explain the vipassanÄ process to NibbÄna) This knowledge from the ending of impermanence and it turns towards NibbÄna. Path Knowledge canâ€™t arise if you do not start from the insight knowledge because itâ€™s proximity conditionâ€”anantara paccayo.


Path Knowledge arises only with the cessation of insight knowledge. Path knowledge arises only once. With this only once can abandon or kill all the corresponding kilesas. Even the Buddha himself wouldnâ€™t teach in details like this. He would start to teach you the contemplation of impermanence.


Even that much, he would come to you only when your spiritual faculties were matured. You must have faith in the Buddha and contemplate with your own wisdom. Faith and wisdom have to be in balance. Wisdom retreats due to over faith in the Buddha. You can see this in the Ven. Vakkaliâ€™s case.


The Buddha had to send him away. Viriya and samÄdhi must in balance towards impermanence. Over viriya the mind is turning towards restlessness. Over samÄdhi is turning toward torpor. Mindfulness is never over. Should have it always, and to watch and observe. In this way will realize the Path and Fruition Knowledge.

ä¸€ä¹å…­äºŒå¹´å…­æœˆåå…­æ—¥

åªæœ‰é€éçŸ¥é“è§€ç…§çš„å°è±¡ï¼Œä½ å€‘æ‰æœƒçŸ¥é“è¦è§€ç…§ä»€éº¼ã€‚å¦å‰‡ï¼Œä½ å€‘åªæ˜¯ååœ¨é‚£è£¡æµªè²»æ™‚é–“ã€‚ä»€éº¼æ˜¯è§€ç…§çš„å°è±¡ï¼Ÿä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œè‹¥çœ¼ç›çœ‹è¦‹è‰²æ³•ï¼Œçœ¼è­˜å°±æœƒç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚é€™æ˜¯è§€ç…§å°è±¡çš„é–‹å§‹ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯ç·£èµ·ï¼ˆD.A.ï¼‰éç¨‹çš„é–‹å§‹ã€‚çœ‹è¦‹ä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œæœƒç”¢ç”Ÿé¸æ“‡å¥½å£çš„æ„Ÿå—ã€‚

åœ¨é‚£ä¸€åˆ»ï¼Œä½ å€‘æ˜¯å¸¶è‘—æ„Ÿå—æ´»è‘—ã€‚çœ‹è¦‹æ˜¯é–‹å§‹ï¼Œé¸æ“‡å¥½å£æ˜¯ç¬¬äºŒå€‹ã€‚è§¸ç·£å—ï¼ˆphassa paccaya vedanÄï¼‰â€”â€”æ¥è§¸ç·£æ„Ÿå—ã€‚é€™ç¨±ç‚ºè¼ªè¿´ï¼ˆsaá¹sÄraï¼‰ã€‚æ„Ÿå—æ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œæ¸´æ„›ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚å—ç·£æ„›ï¼ˆvedanÄ paccaya taá¹‡hÄï¼‰â€”â€”æ„Ÿå—ç·£æ¸´æ„›ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œåœ¨é‚£ä¸€åˆ»ï¼Œä½ å€‘å¸¶è‘—æ¸´æ„›ã€‚ä¹‹å¾Œï¼ŒåŸ·å–å’Œè¡Œç‚ºç”Ÿèµ·ï¼ˆupÄdÄnaá¹å’Œkamma bhavaï¼‰ã€‚é€™äº›æ˜¯è§€ç…§çš„å°è±¡ï¼šâ‘ çœ¼è­˜ â‘¡æ„Ÿå— â‘¢æ¸´æ„› â‘£åŸ·å– â‘¤è¡Œç‚ºã€‚ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹æ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œç¬¬äºŒå€‹ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œç¬¬äºŒå€‹æ­¢æ¯å¾Œï¼Œç¬¬ä¸‰å€‹ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œç­‰ç­‰ã€‚

é€™äº”å€‹å¿ƒè­˜åœ¨ä¸€å€‹éç¨‹ä¸­ã€‚ä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œä½ å€‘æœƒåœ¨ä¾†ä¸–å¾—åˆ°æ–°çš„äº”è˜Šã€‚é€™å°±æ˜¯æ¥­ç·£ç”Ÿï¼ˆkamma paccaya jÄtiï¼‰â€”â€”è¡Œç‚ºç·£å‡ºç”Ÿã€‚å¿ƒè­˜éç¨‹ä¸€å€‹æ¥ä¸€å€‹åœ°ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚å…¶ä»–äº”å€‹æ ¹é–€ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å¦‚æ­¤ã€‚æ•´å¤©å¾å…­æ ¹é–€ç”Ÿèµ·è¡Œç‚ºã€‚æ¯å¤©å‡ºç”Ÿçš„åŸå› éƒ½æ˜¯ä¸å¯è¨ˆæ•¸çš„ã€‚ï¼ˆé€™å°±æ˜¯çœ¾ç”Ÿçš„é–‹å§‹ç„¡æ³•è¾¨åˆ¥çš„åŸå› ã€‚ï¼‰

å› æ­¤ï¼Œèº«æ¥­ã€èªæ¥­å’Œæ„æ¥­çš„å‚µå‹™éå¸¸å¤šã€‚æˆ‘å€‘å¿…é ˆåˆ‡æ–·é€™äº›æ¥­ã€‚å¾çœ¼é–€ï¼Œç”Ÿèµ·è²ªã€ç‹ã€ç™¡ï¼ˆlobha, dosaå’Œmohaï¼‰çš„ä¸‰å€‹ç·£èµ·éç¨‹ã€‚å…¶ä»–é–€ä¹Ÿä»¥é€™ç¨®æ–¹å¼çŸ¥é“ï¼ˆ6 * 3 = 18ï¼‰ã€‚

æ¯å¤©éƒ½æœ‰ä¸å¯è¨ˆæ•¸çš„ä¸å–„æ¥­ã€‚ä½ å€‘åªèƒ½ç”¨é“æ™ºåˆ‡æ–·å®ƒå€‘ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œä½›é™€èªªçœ¾ç”Ÿçš„æ°¸ä¹…ä½æ‰€æ˜¯å››æƒ¡é“ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œåœ¨è¼ªè¿´ä¸­çš„å¾˜å¾Šéå¸¸å¯æ€•ã€‚

ç·£èµ·éç¨‹é¡¯ç¤ºäº†è§€ç…§çš„å°è±¡ã€‚ä½ å€‘ä¸èƒ½ç›²ç›®åœ°åšã€‚åªæœ‰é€éçŸ¥é“ç”Ÿèµ·äº†ä»€éº¼ï¼Œä½ å€‘æ‰æœƒçœ‹åˆ°å®ƒçš„æ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚å¿ƒè­˜ä¸€å€‹æ¥ä¸€å€‹åœ°ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚æ¯å€‹çœ¾ç”Ÿéƒ½å¸¶è‘—ä¸€å€‹å¿ƒè­˜æ´»è‘—ã€‚æ¯å¤©éƒ½æœƒç”Ÿèµ·å¾ˆå¤šæ¥­ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œä½ å€‘å¶çˆ¾æ‰€åšçš„å–„æ¥­èˆ‡å®ƒå€‘ç›¸æ¯”æ˜¯å¾®ä¸è¶³é“çš„ã€‚è‹¥æ²’æœ‰ç·£èµ·éç¨‹ï¼Œä½ å€‘ä¹Ÿç„¡æ³•æ´»è‘—ã€‚è¨˜ä½é€™ä¸€é»ã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘æ²’æœ‰å¾—åˆ°å…§è§€æ™ºï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰é€™äº›æ¥­éƒ½ä¸æœƒè®Šå¾—æ²’æœ‰çµæœã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘ä¸çŸ¥é“å¿…é ˆè§€ç…§ä»€éº¼ï¼Œå°±ä¸æ˜¯æˆ‘çš„éŒ¯ã€‚ä½ å€‘ä¸çŸ¥é“ä½ å€‘èº«ä¸Šç™¼ç”Ÿäº†ä»€éº¼ï¼Œå› æ­¤ç„¡æ³•åšåˆ°ã€‚

æˆ‘æœƒå‘Šè¨´ä½ å€‘å¦‚ä½•è§€ç…§ã€‚è§€ç…§å¿ƒçš„ç„¡å¸¸ï¼Œå¥½çš„æˆ–å£çš„æ„Ÿå—ã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘å¯ä»¥è§€ç…§å®ƒå€‘ï¼Œæ¸´æ„›ã€åŸ·å–å’Œè¡Œç‚ºå°±ç„¡æ³•ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚æ¯æ¬¡ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œé€éè§€ç…§åˆ‡æ–·ç…©æƒ±ã€æ¥­å’Œæœå ±ï¼ˆkilesa, kammaå’ŒvipÄka vaá¹­á¹­asï¼‰çš„è¼ªè¿´ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œé€™æ˜¯è¦æ±‚ä½ å€‘åˆ‡æ–·ä¸‰å€‹è¼ªè¿´ã€‚ä½›é™€å’Œè€å¸«å€‘ä¸€èµ·ç”¨æ™ºæ…§å’Œæ…ˆæ‚²æ•™å°äººå€‘ã€‚è‹¥æ²’æœ‰æ…ˆæ‚²ï¼Œä»–å€‘å°±ä¸æœƒä»˜å‡ºæ™‚é–“ã€‚

ä»–å€‘å¯ä»¥æ•™å°çœŸç†ï¼ˆsaccaï¼‰ï¼Œé€™æ„å‘³è‘—åŒ…æ‹¬æ™ºæ…§ã€‚é€™å…©ç¨®å“è³ªå¿…é ˆä¸€èµ·é€²è¡Œã€‚è‹¥ç¼ºå°‘å…¶ä¸­ä¸€ç¨®ï¼Œå°±ä¸å®Œæ•´ã€‚æ²’æœ‰æ™ºæ…§çš„è«‡è«–æ˜¯æ²’æœ‰ç”¨çš„ã€‚å¾å¼Ÿå­çš„è§’åº¦ä¾†çœ‹ï¼Œä¹Ÿéœ€è¦æ…ˆæ‚²å’Œæ™ºæ…§ã€‚å°è‡ªå·±è¦æœ‰æ…ˆæ‚²ï¼Œæ‰èƒ½å¾è‹¦ä¸­è§£è„«ï¼Œä¸¦è¦æœ‰æ™ºæ…§ä¾†ç†è§£è€å¸«æ‰€èªªçš„è©±ã€‚å°è‡ªå·±è¦æœ‰æ…ˆæ‚²ã€‚

ç”¨æ™ºæ…§è¨˜ä½æˆ‘çš„è«‡è©±ã€‚å¦å‰‡ï¼Œä½ å€‘å¯ä»¥ç²å¾—åŠŸå¾·ï¼Œä½†ç„¡æ³•ç²å¾—æ™ºæ…§ã€‚é€™å°±åƒé’è›™è½ä½›é™€èªªæ³•ä¸€æ¨£ã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘ç‚ºäº†åŠŸå¾·è€Œè½æ³•ï¼Œå°±åƒé’è›™ä¸€æ¨£ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œç”¨äººé¡çš„å¿ƒè½æ³•ã€‚å¦‚ä½•è½æ³•ä¹Ÿå¾ˆé‡è¦ï¼Ÿ

ç•¶ä½ å€‘è§€ç…§ç”Ÿèµ·çš„æ³•ï¼ˆé€™è£¡æ˜¯çœ‹è¦‹ï¼‰æ™‚ï¼Œå®ƒå·²ç¶“æ¶ˆå¤±ï¼Œä¸å†å­˜åœ¨ã€‚ä½ å€‘ä¸æ˜¯å¸¶è‘—çœ‹è¦‹çš„æ„è­˜æ´»è‘—ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å¸¶è‘—é“æ”¯çš„æ„è­˜æ´»è‘—ã€‚æ¯—å©†èˆé‚£çš„è§€ç…§æ˜¯æ”¾æ£„äº”è˜Šï¼Œé€™æ„å‘³è‘—é€™ä¸€é»ã€‚å®ƒä¹Ÿæ˜¯æ”¾æ£„ä¸éš¨æ¸´æ„›å’ŒåŸ·å–è€Œä¾†çš„ç…©æƒ±ã€‚

å› æ­¤ï¼Œå…§è§€æ™ºæ˜¯æ”¾æ£„äº”è˜Šå’Œç…©æƒ±ã€‚é€éæ”¾æ£„äº”è˜Šï¼Œé‚ªè¦‹ä¹Ÿæœƒæ¶ˆå¤±ï¼Œå› ç‚ºæ²’æœ‰ä»€éº¼å¯ä»¥ç¨±ç‚ºäººæˆ–çœ¾ç”Ÿã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘å¾ç„¡ä¸­ç”Ÿæœ‰ï¼Œå°‡å…¶è¦–ç‚ºæˆ‘å’Œæˆ‘çš„ï¼Œé‚£çœŸæ˜¯ç˜‹äº†ã€‚

ï¼ˆé€™ä¸€é»éå¸¸æœ‰è¶£ã€‚è‹¥æˆ‘å€‘ä»”ç´°è§€å¯Ÿå’Œè§€ç…§äººé¡çš„å•é¡Œï¼Œå¤§å¤šæ•¸ç—›è‹¦éƒ½ä¾†è‡ªæ–¼ç„¡ï¼Œåªæ˜¯æ„šè ¢å’Œæ„šæ˜§ã€‚ï¼‰

è‹¥ä½ å€‘å¸¶è‘—æ¯—å©†èˆé‚£çš„å¿ƒè­˜æ­»äº¡ï¼Œå°±æ°¸é ä¸æœƒè®Šå¾—æ²’æœ‰ç”¨è™•ï¼Œå› ç‚ºåœ¨ä½ å€‘åˆ°é”å–„é“å¾Œï¼Œä½ å€‘æœƒé€²å…¥é æµæœï¼ˆã€Šå¢æ”¯éƒ¨å°¼è¿¦è€¶ã€‹ä¸­æœ‰ä½›é™€é—œæ–¼æ­¤äº‹çš„é–‹ç¤ºï¼‰ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œä½ å€‘æ˜¯å¦è­‰å¾—é“æ™ºä¸¦ä¸é‡è¦ã€‚åªè¦ä¿®è¡Œï¼Œå®ƒå°±æœƒæ”¾æ£„æ¸´æ„›å’Œç…©æƒ±ã€‚

ï¼ˆè¥¿äºå¤šç¹¼çºŒè§£é‡‹æ¯—å©†èˆé‚£åˆ°æ¶…æ§ƒçš„éç¨‹ï¼‰é€™ç¨®å¾ç„¡å¸¸æ­¢æ¯è€Œä¾†çš„çŸ¥è­˜æœƒè½‰å‘æ¶…æ§ƒã€‚è‹¥ä½ å€‘ä¸å¾å…§è§€æ™ºé–‹å§‹ï¼Œé“æ™ºå°±ç„¡æ³•ç”Ÿèµ·ï¼Œå› ç‚ºå®ƒæ˜¯è¿‘å–ç·£ï¼ˆanantara paccayoï¼‰ã€‚

é“æ™ºåªåœ¨å…§è§€æ™ºæ­¢æ¯æ™‚ç”Ÿèµ·ã€‚é“æ™ºåªç”Ÿèµ·ä¸€æ¬¡ã€‚åƒ…åƒ…é€™ä¸€æ¬¡å°±å¯ä»¥æ”¾æ£„æˆ–æ¶ˆæ»…æ‰€æœ‰ç›¸æ‡‰çš„ç…©æƒ±ã€‚å³ä½¿ä½›é™€æœ¬äººä¹Ÿä¸æœƒåƒé€™æ¨£è©³ç´°åœ°æ•™å°ã€‚ä»–æœƒé–‹å§‹æ•™å°ä½ å€‘è§€ç…§ç„¡å¸¸ã€‚

å³ä½¿å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œä»–åªæœƒåœ¨ä½ å€‘çš„æ ¹å™¨æˆç†Ÿæ™‚ä¾†æ‰¾ä½ å€‘ã€‚ä½ å€‘å¿…é ˆå°ä½›é™€æœ‰ä¿¡å¿ƒï¼Œä¸¦ç”¨è‡ªå·±çš„æ™ºæ…§è§€ç…§ã€‚ä¿¡å¿ƒå’Œæ™ºæ…§å¿…é ˆå¹³è¡¡ã€‚ç”±æ–¼å°ä½›é™€çš„éåº¦ä¿¡å¿ƒï¼Œæ™ºæ…§æœƒé€€å»ã€‚ä½ å€‘å¯ä»¥åœ¨å©†è¿¦åˆ©å°Šè€…ï¼ˆVen. Vakkaliï¼‰çš„ä¾‹å­ä¸­çœ‹åˆ°é€™ä¸€é»ã€‚

ä½›é™€ä¸å¾—ä¸æŠŠä»–é€èµ°ã€‚ç²¾é€²ï¼ˆviriyaï¼‰å’Œå®šï¼ˆsamÄdhiï¼‰å¿…é ˆåœ¨ç„¡å¸¸æ–¹é¢ä¿æŒå¹³è¡¡ã€‚éåº¦çš„ç²¾é€²æœƒä½¿å¿ƒè½‰å‘èºå‹•ã€‚éåº¦çš„å®šæœƒä½¿å¿ƒè½‰å‘æ˜æ²‰ã€‚æ­£å¿µæ°¸é ä¸æœƒéåº¦ã€‚æ‡‰è©²å§‹çµ‚æ“æœ‰å®ƒï¼Œä¸¦è§€å¯Ÿã€‚å¦‚æ­¤ä¸€ä¾†ï¼Œå°±æœƒè­‰å¾—é“æ™ºå’Œæœæ™ºã€‚


About the Mind



17th June 1962


[Sayadaw gave this talk with his instruction on the contemplation of the mindâ€”Cittaâ€anupassanÄ (or CittÄnupassanÄ), and based on the sutta, the Sheaves of Reeds, Nidanavagga Saá¹ƒyutta (SN.12.67 Naá¸·akalÄpÄ«suttaá¹ƒ). In the sutta Ven. SÄriputta and MahÄkoá¹­á¹­hita were discussing on the relation between consciousness and name and form (viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ and nÄmaâ€rÅ«pam), and practice. Sayadaw gave a simple instruction on cittÄnupassanÄ.


The six external guest minds are: â‘  eyeâ€consciousness â‘¡ Earâ€consciousness â‘¢ Noseâ€consciousness â‘£ Tongueâ€consciousness (seeing, hearing, smelling and tasting) â‘¤ + â‘¥ Bodyâ€consciousness, pleasant and painful consciousness of the mind, arise in the whole body except the hairs, the nails and the dry skins.


These consciousnesses are called external guest minds because they donâ€™t arise all the times. With the knowing of the place of arising and will know the passing away.


The six internal guest minds are: in the heart; â‘  Greedâ€”lobha â‘¡ Hatredâ€”dosa â‘¢ Delusionâ€”moha (restlessnessâ€”uddhacca) â‘£ Nonâ€greedâ€”alobha (giving, offering) â‘¤ Nonâ€hatredâ€”adosa (love, kindness) â‘¥ Thoughts (thinking, planning, etc.).


All these twelve minds have to contemplate when they arise. Without them arising there are always two host minds exist. These are: â‘  The mind wanting to breathe in, and â‘¡ the mind wanting to breathe out. These are totally 14 minds for contemplation.


Minds arise depending on forms. Seeing consciousness arises in the form of the eye. So, note it as name and form (nÄma and rÅ«pa). The others also know in this way. They arise accordingly at their places as name and form. The internal guest minds and the host minds are arising depending on the heart base; they are also name and form.


Whatever mind arises depends on form. So, note it as name and form arise, name and form (nÄma and rÅ«pa) are seeing, name and from are hearing, etc. So, you get the knowledge of mind and formâ€”NÄmaâ€rÅ«papariggaha Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ (Ã±Äá¹‡a). Again all minds arise with the contact of senseâ€objects and senseâ€doors.


So, they are cause and effect process. Therefore, doubt falls away. Knowing as only mind and form exist and wrong view falls away. You get the two knowing knowledge


(i.e., NÄmaâ€rÅ«pa pariggaha Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ and Paccayapariggaha Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹) = (knowledge of mind and matter and knowledge of the conditions)


You donâ€™t get the contemplative knowledge yet. For the contemplation of impermanence, still need the teacher to show you the knowledge of comprehension and rise and fall (SammasanaÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹ and udayabbaya Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹)


Sayadaw used the MilindapaÃ±ha text for vipassanÄ instruction. King Milinda requested the instruction from Ven. NÄgasena. He answered to him that when tiger wanted to catch its prey it would not chase them, but waiting and watching behind a bush to kill its prey. In this way the yogiâ€”tiger behind a samÄdhi bush watching and observing the cittasâ€”preys which are arising from the six sensesâ€doors.


Behind the samÄdhiâ€”bush, the yogiâ€”tiger has to catch the minds of the preys. Here the tiger represents the yogi or knowledge (Ã±Äá¹‡a); the preys represent the minds or impermanences, or feelings, etc. Ã‘Äá¹‡a catches on the impermanence, or magga is in accordance with the passing away. Not all of the 14 minds arise together.


In every mind moment only one mind arises that there is no way not to catch on it. CittÄnupassanÄâ€”hiding and catching the minds; catching the minds with samÄdhi and paÃ±Ã±Ä; contemplate of the minds again and again. AnupassanÄ means contemplate for many times.


The commentary encouraged to use cittÄnupassanÄ because most people take the mind as a self or soul (this point is quite evident because even some Buddhists are using the mind as a soul and a self to teach people. I met an elderly MahÄyana monk before; he said that how you could take rebirth if you didnâ€™t have a soul. The mind as a soul is a very deep rooted view in the religions and philosophies.


Even western scientists making research on rebirth had this wrong view. The Buddha condemned it strongly in the sutta (see the monk SÄti in the MahÄtaá¹‡hÄ-saá¹…khaya Sutta, Majjhima NikÄya, MN.38/(8) MahÄtaá¹‡hÄsaá¹…khayasuttaá¹ƒ). Also, the first stage of realization is abandoning wrong views. A yogi whose nature is diá¹­á¹­hi carita and dull faculty is suitable for cittÄnupassanÄ.


But for most yogis' experiences, the mind is quite subtle in the beginnings of practice. So in the suttas of mindfulness, it started from the coarser one to the subtler one, i.e., form â†’ feeling â†’ mind â†’ dhamma. ]


Watch with good samÄdhi. You canâ€™t contemplate without samÄdhi. After establish good samÄdhi, watching and contemplate behind the bush of samÄdhi. The tiger of Yogi/knowledge is watching and catching the preys of impermanence. Here I give you the clear instruction.


The tiger of knowledge is eating the preys of the mind or contemplate impermanence. Therefore the knowledge is in accordance with the impermanence. The 14 types of minds are preys. If you are waiting and catching them and will get it. You caught them in dead or the vanishing. CittÄnupassanÄ means watching and catching the minds again and again is contemplation of the minds.


In the Satipaá¹­á¹­hÄna Sutta the Buddha also included the ariyan minds. Can you contemplate them which you donâ€™t have? (As a teacher he had to teach in a complete form. It doesnâ€™t mean we have to do all of them). The worldlings only have these 14 types of minds. Therefore itâ€™s necessary to justify the text. These were teaching for the worldling and the ariyans, etc.


You have to note this one, vipassanÄ is watching and catching. Ven. NÄgasena taught king Milinda in this way. If you contemplate it with searching and itâ€™s a concept (paÃ±Ã±Äti). If you are watching and contemplating whatever arising is ultimate reality (paramattha).


The two arahants were discussing on the contemplation of the mind (here, Ven. SÄriputta and MahÄkoá¹­á¹­hita). The Buddha also supported them. So you have to practice it without any doubt. And also looking for a teacher who can teach the Dhamma becomes not wanting and revulsion toward the mind. Then he is a speaker of the Dhamma (Dhammakathika).


If you can practice become not wanting and revulsion towards them is a person practicing in accordance with the Dhamma (DhammÄnuâ€dhammappaá¹­ipatti). You may realize NibbÄna in this life if you can continue to practice towards the end of the mind or abandoning clinging. We canâ€™t conquer the mind that arriving to this plane and that plane. It happens accordingly to the mind. In saá¹sÄra, it makes us shameful and no benefit at all.


So we shouldnâ€™t associate with this mind. I am teaching you become revulsion and disenchantment toward the mind. We canâ€™t control our minds that with birth consciousness and become chicks (get the birth of a chick). The beak, wings, etc. are making by this mind. It is in accordance with the clinging of the mind.


In the same ways, you do not become a human being if you are arriving into a cowâ€™s womb. And you become a calf according to the mind. Kamma is throwing you there. After arriving there and the mind creates the shape and form. Becoming different animals are creating by the minds, and not kammas. Doing the rebirthâ€linking (paá¹­isandhi) is kamma. Become different kinds of beings are by the mind. Kamma sent you to human life and your human form was made by the mind.


If kamma creates there is only has one kind of hell. But there are many different kinds of hells and make by the mind. Between kamma and mind, the mind is more fearful. When we are speaking, we donâ€™t say I canâ€™t control my kamma. Instead we are saying; â€œI canâ€™t control my mind.â€


The Buddha gave the example of an artistâ€™s mind. Many fancy pictures arise from the artistâ€™s mind.


(We can see this in modern art; some strange stories and novels create by human minds. Even some later Buddhists used this important of the mind and postulated extreme theory of the mind. Everything is mind made and itâ€™s the only real existence. This is an extreme theory if we careful study D. A. process.).


Therefore, the Buddha said that mind was the creator and making many different kinds of fancy things. At night seeing a tree stump and taking it as a ghost and frighten.


This is making by the mind. Some people canâ€™t control their minds and commit suicide by hanging themselves. Not kammas hang them. People talk about suicide as it will repeat again for 500 time in five aeons (It is a Burmese saying). This was never mentioned in the text books.


They frighten people not to commit suicide. Next life, if having the chance to meet good teachers even can become arahant. The mind in pain is more fearful than physical pain. For an example, if someone hits with a thorn in the dark and takes it as bitten by a snake and itâ€™s more difficult to treat.


(Continue to talk on cittÄnupassanÄ) You only become for death if you are talking about no mind to contemplate, because beings are alive with the minds (except only the nonâ€percipient Brahma Godâ€without mind).


So donâ€™t make yourself becoming a fool. Contemplate the death (mind) with the alive (mind). Minds which disappear are dead (mind). Contemplate oneâ€™s own death with the Ã±Äá¹‡a mind which is connecting by kamma (i.e., the near death kamma from last life sent to this life).


We have to send the body to the graveyard if the next mind is not arising. The mind now is the next new mind of Ko Saw Maung (a disciple in the audience). Contemplating the dead (mind) with the alive (mind) is vipassanÄ.


Do you become disenchanted after seeing a lot of deaths (i.e., oneâ€™s own death)? Sure you will. And then you donâ€™t want these kinds of mind again. In this way, you become a person practice in accordance with the Dhamma.

â†’ è‡ªæ®ºè€…ï¼Œå¤šå› ä¸èƒ½æ‰¿å—å¿ƒä¹‹è‹¦ï¼Œä¸¦éæ¥­åŠ›æ¨å‹•ä¸ŠåŠã€‚

ï¼ˆç·¬ç”¸ä¿—èªæœ‰äº‘ï¼šã€Œè‡ªæ®ºè€…äº”å¤§åŠ«äº”ç™¾æ¬¡é‡è¤‡æ­¤è¡Œã€ï¼Œå…¶å¯¦æ­¤èªªéè¦‹æ–¼æ­£å…¸ï¼‰

å°±å¦‚ï¼š

â†’ å¤œé–“è¢«åˆºï¼Œèª¤ä»¥ç‚ºè¢«è›‡å’¬ï¼Œç”¢ç”Ÿæ›´å¤§é©šæã€‚

â— ä¿®è§€å¿ƒï¼Œå°±æ˜¯ã€Œä»¥ç”Ÿè€…è§€æ­»è€…ã€

â†’ æ‰€æœ‰å·²æ»…ä¹‹å¿ƒï¼Œå³æ˜¯ã€Œæ­»å¿ƒã€

â†’ ä»¥ç•¶ä¸‹ç”Ÿèµ·ä¹‹ã€Œè§€æ™ºä¹‹å¿ƒã€ï¼Œå»è§€ç…§ã€Œå·²æ»…ä¹‹å¿ƒã€
â†’ å³æ˜¯ä»¥ã€Œç”Ÿå¿ƒè§€æ­»å¿ƒã€ï¼è§€å¿ƒéš¨å¿µ

è­¬å¦‚ï¼šç¾åœ¨é€™ä¸€å¿µï¼Œæ˜¯æŸ¯æƒè²Œå¼Ÿå­çš„ã€Œæ–°å¿ƒã€ï¼Œ
â†’ æ¥çºŒéå»è‡¨çµ‚çš„æ¥­åŠ›æ‰€ç‰½ä¹‹ã€Œæ­»å¿ƒã€è€Œä¾†ã€‚

â†’ è‹¥ç„¡æ–°å¿ƒçºŒèµ·ï¼Œå³é ˆé€å¾€å¢“åœ°ï¼ˆæ­»äº¡ï¼‰

ä½ çœ‹è¦‹é€™éº¼å¤šæ¬¡çš„ã€Œå¿ƒä¹‹æ­»ã€ï¼Œ

â†’ å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œä¾¿æ˜¯ä¾æ³•ä¿®è¡Œè€…ã€‚
